content.question: Outboard ailerons are (1) _____ at (2) _____ speeds, to prevent (3) _____.

options.A: (1) unlocked; (2) high; (3) aeroelastic phenomena.
options.B: (1) locked; (2) low; (3) aeroelastic phenomena.
options.C: (1) unlocked; (2) low; (3) aileron reversal.
options.D: (1) locked; (2) high; (3) aileron reversal.

key_points: OUTBOARD AND INBOARD AILERONS Two sets of ailerons may be fitted, one at the wing tips (outboard ailerons) and one set inboard (inboard ailerons)

At low speeds, both the inboard and the outboard ailerons are controllable but once the aircraft gains speed (usually when the flaps are all the way up) only the inboard ailerons respond to control input
At high speeds, when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion, outboard (low-speed) ailerons are "locked-out"
learning.explanation: OUTBOARD AND INBOARD AILERONS Two sets of ailerons may be fitted, one at the wing tips (outboard ailerons) and one set inboard (inboard ailerons). At low speeds, both the inboard and the outboard ailerons are controllable but once the aircraft gains speed (usually when the flaps are all the way up) only the inboard ailerons respond to control input. At high speeds, when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion, outboard (low-speed) ailerons are "locked-out". Due to wing elasticity, the effectiveness of outboard ailerons reduces or even aileron reversal can occur at higher speeds.

content.question: Which of the following tab devices contributes positively to the effectiveness of a control surface?

options.A: A trim tab.
options.B: An anti-balance tab.
options.C: A servo tab.
options.D: A balance tab.

key_points: Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load
Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls
This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe
learning.explanation: Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load. Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls. This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe. To counteract these characteristics and assist the pilot to use the control surfaces correctly it is necessary to have anti-balance tabs fitted. These operate in the opposite sense to the balance tab by deflecting the anti-balance tab in the same direction as that of the primary control surface and increase the aerodynamic loading.

Consider two elevator control systems:
1. is fitted with a trim tab
2. is fitted with fully powered hydraulic controls and an adjustable horizontal stabiliser.
For both cases and starting from a trimmed condition, how will the neutral position of the control column change, after trimming for a speed increase?

options.C: 1 does not change, 2 does not change.

key_points: When speed is increased, angle of attack must be decreased, therefore the aircraft must be trimmed nose down otherwise the pilot will have to keep pushing the control column forward in order to keep level flight
When a trim tab is installed, in this case, it will move up in order to maintain the new elevator deflection
The control column is then held in a more forward position
learning.explanation: When speed is increased, angle of attack must be decreased, therefore the aircraft must be trimmed nose down otherwise the pilot will have to keep pushing the control column forward in order to keep level flight. When a trim tab is installed, in this case, it will move up in order to maintain the new elevator deflection. The control column is then held in a more forward position. Remember that the trim tab is deflected in the opposite direction than the elevator. For a trimmable horizontal stabiliser, the whole stabiliser's incidence angle can be changes as trimming. The pilot can control the stabiliser by using the trim wheel. If the linkage is mechanic or power-assisted, the neutral point of the control column changes with trim setting. However, in a fully powered flight control system, neutral point will not change since there is no actual trim, only a feel unit (if you are trimmed, the elevator deflection is 0).

content.question: Consider an aircraft equipped with roll spoilers during a turn. Which spoilers are most likely to extend, and on which wing?

options.A: The outboard spoilers on the downgoing wing.
options.B: The inboard spoilers on the downgoing wing
options.C: The outboard spoilers on the upgoing wing
options.D: The inboard spoilers on the up-going wing

key_points: To function as a lateral control, the spoilers rise on the wing with the up-going aileron (down-going wing), proportional to the aileron input
On the wing with the down-going aileron, they remain retracted
Unlike ailerons, spoilers cannot give an increase of lift, so a roll manoeuvre controlled by spoilers will give a net loss of lift
learning.explanation: To function as a lateral control, the spoilers rise on the wing with the up-going aileron (down-going wing), proportional to the aileron input. On the wing with the down-going aileron, they remain retracted. Unlike ailerons, spoilers cannot give an increase of lift, so a roll manoeuvre controlled by spoilers will give a net loss of lift. However, the spoiler has several advantages compared to the aileron: - There is no adverse yaw. - Wing twisting is reduced. - At transonic speed, its effectiveness is not reduced by shock wave induced flow separation. - They cannot develop flutter. - Spoilers do not occupy the trailing edge, which can be utilised for more flaps. An example is illustrated in the attached figure. Speed brakes have been selected, and then a turn to the left is initiated. The spoiler surfaces on the wing with the up-going aileron will stay deployed, or modulate upwards, depending on the speed brake selection and the roll input. The spoiler surfaces on the wing with the down-going aileron will modulate towards the stowed position. The spoiler surfaces on the wing with the down-going aileron may partially or fully stow, again depending on the speed brake selection and the roll input. Note: Roll control spoilers are generally distributed throughout the wing, and the system depends on pilot input to modulate the degree of deflection and which spoilers to extend or retract. On this question, it seems that EASA considers the most likely to extend to be the outboard spoilers. key_points: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement
In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from trim or equilibrium
The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane
learning.explanation: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement. In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from trim or equilibrium. The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane. The position of the CG not only affects the positive longitudinal static stability, it also affects the pitch handling characteristics. When the elevators are deflected, the pitching moment they produce must be greater than the restoring moment of the airplane’s positive longitudinal static stability. For any given elevator deflection there is a small response if the aircraft CG is located forward (i.e. stable condition) and a large response for the same angle of deflection when the aircraft CG is located at an aft position (i.e. a less-stable condition). The elevator deflection required to counter a forward CG movement during a maneuver having a load factor greater than one is increased.

content.question: If the thrust line is above the CG, how will this affect the airplane?

options.A: Pitch down, stabilising.
options.B: Pitch down, destabilising.
options.C: Pitch up, stabilizing.
options.D: Pitch up, destabilising.

key_points: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability
The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
learning.explanation: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability. The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. Therefore, the effect is destabilizing. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

content.question: A transport aircraft has to carry some heavy cargo aft of the CG location. The cargo would ideally be placed further forwards within the aircraft, but it is very difficult to move. The Captain verifies that the aircraft is within CG limits currently, and continues with the flight preparation. What is the effect on stick force stability and how does the leading edge of the variable-incidence horizontal stabiliser move due to this cargo?

options.A: Stick force stability is increased and the stabiliser leading edge moves down.
options.B: Stick force stability is increased and the stabiliser leading edge moves up.
options.C: Stick force stability is decreased and the stabiliser leading edge moves up.
options.D: Stick force stability is decreased and the stabiliser leading edge moves down.

key_points: Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft
When the aircraft's CG (Centre of Gravity) is located far forwards within the aircraft, the aircraft's stability is high, and its manoeuvrability is low
When the CG is located further aft, the aircraft is less stable, but more manoeuvrable
learning.explanation: Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft. When the aircraft's CG (Centre of Gravity) is located far forwards within the aircraft, the aircraft's stability is high, and its manoeuvrability is low. When the CG is located further aft, the aircraft is less stable, but more manoeuvrable. Pitch manoeuvrability is measured by the "stick force per G" (stick force stability), meaning how much force the pilot needs to apply to the controls to gain an extra 1G of vertical acceleration. The higher the stick force stability, the lower the manoeuvrability, so in this question, as the CG has been moved aft by the cargo, the manoeuvrability will be increased, so the stick force stability will decrease. The second part of this question is about the aircraft's trim in relation to the CG location. Most large jet aircraft calculate different pitch trim settings to use for take-off, depending on the position of the CG and the take-off mass of the aircraft. This is so the pilot can always feel roughly the same force when rotating the aircraft, and during the first phase of flight. The trim is often done (and in this question certainly done) by an all moving tailplane, known as a variable-incidence horizontal stabiliser, so the whole stabiliser moves to perform the act of trimming. If the aircraft has a far forward CG location, the nose will feel heavy to the pilot, so during the setup, the pilots will set a much more nose-up trim setting, so that at rotation, the feeling will be roughly the same. This is what the question is referring to. Adding extra cargo behind the CG will move the CG backwards, making the aircraft more tail heavy. This will require more nose-down stabiliser trim to feel the same on take-off. A nose-down stabiliser trim is caused by providing less downforce (or extra lift force) on the tail. That is created by setting the horizontal stabiliser at a higher angle, with its leading edge pointing more upwards. This will be the same during the cruise, where less nose down moment will be required, so the leading edge of the stabiliser will be pointing more upwards than if the cargo was not loaded.

content.question: To counter adverse yaw, an aircraft has aileron/rudder coupling. In a right turn, the left aileron goes (1) _____, the right aileron goes (2) _____, and the rudder automatically moves to the (3) _____.

options.A: (1) down; (2) up; (3) right.
options.B: (1) up; (2) up; (3) right.
options.C: (1)down; (2) down; (3) left.
options.D: (1) up; (2) down; (3) left.

key_points: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft
Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron
This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft. Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron. This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis. Since this yaw is adverse (i.e., in a banked turn to the left, the yaw is to the right), it is opposing the turn, which is detrimental to the aircraft's performance. To counter adverse yaw, some aircraft incorporate aileron/rudder coupling which is a system that automatically applies a rudder input in a turn to counter the adverse yawing moments generated by the ailerons. In a right turn, the left wing lift is increased by lowering the aileron. As we have described above, increased lift, increases induced drag, which generates a yawing moment in the opposite direction. As a result, the aircraft will be in an unbalanced turn. To re-balance the turn, right rudder must be applied.

content.question: How is adverse yaw compensated for during entry into and roll out from a turn?

options.A: Horn balanced controls.
options.B: Differential aileron deflection.
options.C: Servo tabs.
options.D: Anti-balanced rudder control.

key_points: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft
Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron
This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft. Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron. This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis. Since this yaw is adverse (i.e., in a banked turn to the left, the yaw is to the right), it is opposing the turn, which is detrimental to the aircraft's performance. Adverse (aileron) yaw is corrected in the design by the use of either differential ailerons or Frise ailerons. The differential aileron deflection system ensures that the drag generated by both ailerons when rolling into or out of a turn is equal, thus eliminating adverse yaw. This is achieved by constructing the aileron system such that the angular deflection of the upgoing aileron is always proportionately greater than the deflection of the down going aileron.

options.A: Pitch control.
options.B: Rudder pedal motion.

If you encounter this question during your official exam, kindly inform us
learning.explanation: Note: This question was formulated with limited feedback. We suspect it pertains to the learning objectives listed below. If you encounter this question during your official exam, kindly inform us. We appreciate your assistance. 081.05.07.01.01: Explain which parameters may be controlled in level flight with the pitch control law. Fly-by-wire is a sophisticated system that substitutes the traditional manual-mechanical flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface. Within this system, a computer interface is interposed between the pilots and the final control surfaces. Modern commercial fly-by-wire aircraft integrate a flight-envelope protection system into their flight control software, which is housed within the flight control computer. This protection system serves the crucial role of preventing pilots from issuing control commands that could push the aircraft beyond its structural and aerodynamic operational boundaries. In the realm of fly-by-wire technology, the concept of flight envelope and maneuvering envelope protections is employed. These are governed by predefined control laws that serve as a set of rules, guiding the computers in transforming input signals. One of the most commonly used control laws involves managing the load factor in pitch control. Essentially, this means that the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS) adjusts its position to maintain a specific load factor. When the pilot manipulates the sidestick, the THS moves accordingly, altering the load factor proportionally to the sidestick's deflection (refer to the attached diagram). This means that as long as the sidestick remains untouched, the aircraft will maintain its flight-path-angle-corrected load factor. For example, if the aircraft is in straight and level flight and the pilot pulls the sidestick, the aircraft will follow a curved trajectory, increasing its pitch angle until the sidestick is released.

options.D: The elevator is the primary control surface for control about the lateral axis and is operated by a forward or backward movement of the control wheel or stick.

key_points: Control of the airplane about its lateral axis, or pitch control, is accomplished by using the elevators
The elevators are hinged control surfaces located on the horizontal tail plane usually at the rear of the airplane
A forward movement of the control column (stick) by the pilot will cause the elevators to go down and a backward movement will cause them to go up
learning.explanation: Control of the airplane about its lateral axis, or pitch control, is accomplished by using the elevators. The elevators are hinged control surfaces located on the horizontal tail plane usually at the rear of the airplane. A forward movement of the control column (stick) by the pilot will cause the elevators to go down and a backward movement will cause them to go up. The effect produced by the elevators is to increase the camber of the tail plane when the stick is pushed forward, which causes an increase of tail plane lift and an upward force on the underside of the control surface that results in the airplane rotating about its lateral axis through the CG and the nose being depressed. The opposite is true when the stick is pulled back, the camber is negative, and the lift generated is downward which when trimmed becomes the counterbalancing force required for longitudinal equilibrium.

In any conventional aircraft, the application of rudder will cause some secondary effect of roll, usually towards the direction that the rudder was applied. This effect is very strong in swept wing aircraft, and very noticeable when flying them, hence the reason most jets of this kind are flown without the use of the rudder pedals except for engine failures and crosswind take-offs and landings. Using full rudder deflection only to intercept the final approach course is a terrible idea as the aircraft will violently roll to the right. This is because the left wing will be significantly accelerated through a much longer arc that the right wing, which conversely gets a much reduced speed of airflow during that motion, causing a large right wing drop, and the right wing could even stall if the effect were large enough to increase the right wing's angle of attack above the critical AoA. As for the other answers: The left wing would not stall as there is greater airspeed over it and with no significant increase of angle of attack. Adverse yaw is a secondary effect which occurs when ailerons are used for roll purposes, so does not really apply to this situation. learning.explanation: The three axes of an airplane intersect at the center of gravity (CG) and are those about which an airplane moves in flight. They are the longitudinal, the lateral and the normal axes. If the forces about any axis are not balanced there will be an angular acceleration and the airplane will rotate about that axis. The horizontal straight line joining the most forward point of the fuselage of the airplane, the center of the nose, to the center of the most rearward point of the airplane’s fuselage is the longitudinal axis. It is often referred to as the roll axis because the airplane, in response to a control input by the pilot or as the result of an external disturbance, drops one wing and raises the other. Thus, it rotates or rolls about the longitudinal axis. The flight controls enable the pilot to rotate the airplane about its three axes. The ailerons and the rudder cause the airplane to roll about its longitudinal axis, the elevators enable the airplane to pitch around its lateral axis and the rudder allows the airplane to yaw around its normal axis.

learning.explanation: Note: this question is much too vague to be able to correctly work out in its current format. There are so many clarifying questions that need to be asked in order to work out the second part of the question correctly. Therefore, we will explain to you the basics here, then you can let us know if you see it in the exam, and what the correct answer was (or if the question/options were different at all), thank you! This comes back to stability, and longitudinal stability in particular (stability in pitch). Think of a stable aircraft like a throwing dart, weight at the front, fins at the back, and it is incredibly stable flying through the air, always landing facing into the dartboard. This is the same for an aircraft, and we have to make our "weight" (Centre of Gravity, CG) in front of our "wings", which are dictated by the Centre of Pressure (CP)/Centre of lift (CL) of our wings and other aerodynamic features. The "neutral point" is the average location of the pressure effects from all our wings, fuselage, engine cowlings and other aerodynamic features, sort of the balanced centre of pressure of the whole aircraft. As long as our CG is in front of our neutral point, then the aircraft will be longitudinally stable. Also, the weight, acting through the CG, is not in line with all the lift, acting through the CP. This means that the further forward weight will cause a nose-down moment. We obviously have to counteract this moment, and this is why the tailplane is tasked with providing a downwards force on the aircraft tail, causing a balancing nose-up moment. Of course, the movement of the CG and CP can change how much downforce the tail needs to produce. If the CG moves further forwards, the tailplane has to produce higher downforce to counteract the larger nose down moment, and vice-versa. The way that the tailplane produces downforce is two-fold. It usually has a low/negative angle of incidence, to provide a negative angle of attack, and the downwash from the wings causes an even larger negative angle of attack, particularly at high aircraft AoA (low speed), when the wing downwash angle is greater. This is why tailplanes have elevators, to change their angle of attack for control, and for trimming at different speeds. This does not unfortunately help us get a solid answer for this question. Of course, the increased speed means a higher airflow over the tailplane, but also leads to decreased downwash angle from the main wing (due to lower angle of attack), but now with a more negative angle of attack without accounting for downwash due to the lower pitch angle of the aeroplane. These are opposing effects, and without knowing the aircraft and speed range, it is really very difficult to say whether the force increases or decreases. Our tendency is to say that the downwash angle and pitch angle mostly cancel each other out, and that the increased airflow increases the down-force of the tailplane. We can also justify this by saying that when an aircraft gets faster, we have to trim down, which is us artificially decreasing the downforce of our tailplane via the elevator, this means the downforce must have been too large after the speed increase, therefore the force increased. We do not like having to use this as an justification, as there are other forces at play, but it works quite well for everyone to understand.

learning.explanation: There are two scenarios that this could be; a faulty autopilot or trim runaway. A faulty autopilot would be exactly as it sounds, the autopilot is inputting the incorrect command into the control system, and the feedback loop is not working correctly to fix it. The fix for this situation would be disconnecting the autopilot. Of course, the pilots must then be aware that the trim will be set massively different from normal, so the forces will be high upon autopilot disconnect. The other situation is a trim runaway. It is impossible to tell from the question whether this is the situation or not. A trim runaway is where the electric trim system of an aircraft continues changing the trim angle, without command from the pilots. It could be due to the trims themselves, or the trims commanded by the autopilot. It is then up to the pilot to choose whether to disconnect the autopilot or not, as leaving the autopilot running reduces the forces the pilots have to bear, but disconnecting could fix the problem entirely. Therefore, first, the pilot must disconnect the autopilot to stop any autopilot fault from making the situation worse. They should then attempt to control the aircraft manually, and if the trim runaway continues, switch off the electric trim and trim manually. On balance, we would say that both of the actions in the question are correct, and with pretty much correct reasoning, although there will be an order in which to do these actions, set out by the manufacturer. learning.explanation: The CG location plays a crucial role in the stability and control of the aircraft. If the CG is too far forward, the aircraft may be excessively nose-heavy, making it difficult to rotate during takeoff. If the CG is too far aft, the aircraft may be excessively tail-heavy, leading to difficulty in controlling the pitch attitude. When an aircraft has an aft center of gravity (CG), it will tend to rotate rapidly during takeoff and naturally adopt a high nose attitude during climb-out. Conversely, if the CG is forward (nose-heavy), the opposite effect will occur. To counterbalance these tendencies and ensure a smooth takeoff, the position of the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS) is adjusted. This adjustment aims to achieve two goals: first, to maintain a standard rotation rate, and second, to facilitate the aircraft settling into the desired climb-out attitude with minimal trim adjustments.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct in the event of computer failure on a fly-by-wire (FBW) aircraft?

options.A: Some form of back-up mode is required in the event of total computer failure.
options.B: In “Direct Law”, mechanical linkage to all control surfaces remains available.
options.C: Control of the aircraft is lost if the computer system fails completely.
options.D: Any form of computer failure will affect the aircraft handling.

key_points: The fly-by-wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The fly-by-wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

content.question: Which statement about a primary control surface controlled by a servo tab, is correct?

options.A: Due to the effectiveness of the servo tab the control surface area can be smaller.
options.B: The servo tab can also be used as a balance tab.
options.C: The control effectiveness of the primary surface is increased by servo tab deflection.
options.D: The position is undetermined during taxiing, in particular with tailwind.

key_points: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable
To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function
In this setup, the flying control is connected to a small servo tab mounted on the trailing edge of the main control surface, rather than directly to the control surface itself
learning.explanation: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable. To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function. In this setup, the flying control is connected to a small servo tab mounted on the trailing edge of the main control surface, rather than directly to the control surface itself. Moving the servo tab generates a force that moves the main control surface. In summary, the control surface is only moved by aerodynamic forces while the servo tab is moved directly by the pilot. Regarding this question: Imagine the aircraft is parked with no wind and the flight controls are not locked. The control surface would tilt down due to gravity. If the pilot moves the controls, only the servo tab moves; the control surface stays tilted down. When taxiing with a headwind, the control surface can level out due to aerodynamic forces. The pilot can then adjust the angle using the servo tab, though less effectively than in flight. If taxiing with a tailwind stronger than the aircraft's speed, the relative wind from behind can push the control surface up or down, depending on its previous position. Thus, the statement that "the position is undetermined during taxiing, in particular with tailwind" is correct.

content.question: One method to compensate adverse yaw is:

options.A: a differential aileron.
options.B: an anti-balance tab.
options.C: a balance tab.
options.D: a balance panel.

key_points: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases
Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing
These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing
learning.explanation: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases. Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing. These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing. This is adverse yaw, which is particularly significant at low airspeeds because of the large aileron deflection necessary to achieve the same rate of roll as at higher speeds with less deflection. Adverse yaw may be counteracted by any one of the following devices: rudder/aileron coupling. slot/aileron coupling. spoiler/aileron coupling. frise ailerons. differential aileron deflection. The differential aileron deflection system ensures that the drag generated by both ailerons when rolling into or out of a turn is equal, thus eliminating adverse yaw. This is achieved by constructing the aileron system such that the angular deflection of the upgoing aileron is always proportionately greater than the deflection of the down going aileron.

content.question:
Comparing the differences between a horizontal trimmable stabiliser and an elevator trim tab, which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
I. A elevator trim tab is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes.
II. A trim tab runaway causes less control difficulty.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
An elevator trim tab is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes
" INCORRECT The design of the majority of airliners and transport aircraft incorporates a trimmable horizontal stabilizer which features a fully moving horizontal tail surface
learning.explanation: "I. An elevator trim tab is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes." INCORRECT The design of the majority of airliners and transport aircraft incorporates a trimmable horizontal stabilizer which features a fully moving horizontal tail surface. The trimmable stabilizer's primary advantage is that it provides tremendous trimming power over the full speed range of the airplane since the entire stabiliser may be moved to trim the aircraft. Summary: A trimmable horizontal stabiliser is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes. "II. A trim tab runaway causes less control difficulty." CORRECT Runaway trim occurs when the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS) or other trim devices on the aircraft tail fails to stop at the desired position and continues to deflect up or down. A trim tab is much smaller than a trimmable horizontal stabiliser. Therefore, if it runs to the wrong position, it will produce smaller forces than a THS, thus causing less control difficuty.

content.question: On an airliner with stabiliser trim, an extra baggage container is loaded into the front hold, forward of the CG. When the pilot makes an adjustment to the take-off trim, how will the stabiliser move?

options.A: The stabiliser does not move, but the elevator will be deflected downwards.
options.B: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.
options.C: The trailing edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.
options.D: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be raised.

key_points: Adding an extra load to the front hold will move the CG forward
The aircraft will have to be trimmed for nose-up
A tail-heavy airplane (trimmed for nose-down) would require the stabilizer to be deflected up
learning.explanation: Adding an extra load to the front hold will move the CG forward. The aircraft will have to be trimmed for nose-up. A tail-heavy airplane (trimmed for nose-down) would require the stabilizer to be deflected up. When the variable incidence tail plane is trimmed, it has no elevator deflection. The opposite is also true for an airplane trimmed for nose up: it would require the stabilizer to be deflected down. When the variable incidence tail plane is trimmed, it has no elevator deflection. When trimmed for a forward CG position (nose heavy), the stabiliser leading edge is lower than the trailing edge.

content.question: On a jet transport aircraft flying at (1) _____ speeds, the outboard ailerons are (2) _____ to prevent (3) _____.

options.A: (1) low; (2) locked; (3) geometric washout
options.B: (1) low, (2) unlocked; (3) geometric washout
options.C: (1) high; (2) locked; (3) control reversal
options.D: (1) high; (2) unlocked; (3) control reversal

key_points: Ailerons are the control surface on an aircraft that controls roll
They are usually mounted at the tips of the wings, to create the largest moment arm between them and the centre of gravity, for greater effectiveness
This can become problematic, particularly at high speeds
learning.explanation: Ailerons are the control surface on an aircraft that controls roll. They are usually mounted at the tips of the wings, to create the largest moment arm between them and the centre of gravity, for greater effectiveness. This can become problematic, particularly at high speeds. At high speeds, the forces on a control surface are so great that they can actually twist the wing they are connected to. The further outboard the ailerons are, the easier it is to cause the wing to twist, as it has less stiffness. Imagine a down-going aileron, used to increase the lift of the wing and make the wing rise. This would also twist the wing so its trailing edge was up, and therefore the leading edge goes down, causing the wing to lose lift, and the wing would drop, instead of rising. We call this aileron reversal, shown in the annex above. This is why many high speed aircraft often have secondary ailerons, which are called inboard ailerons, much closer to the fuselage, that are used during high speed flight, and the outboard ailerons are locked in place to avoid control reversal, flutter, and other structural issues due to the high aerodynamic forces. Some aircraft use roll spoilers also. There is also a low speed aileron reversal that happens near the stall, so be aware of the similar names.

content.question: Which of the following aerodynamic balancing device enables big control surface change/movement with relatively small force needed to apply?

options.A: Anti-balance Tab.
options.B: Balance Tab.
options.C: Horn Balance.
options.D: Servo Tab.

key_points: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable
To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function
The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column
learning.explanation: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable. To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function. The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column. There is no direct link between the control column and the primary control surface. The function and operation of the servo-tab is the same as the balance tab and moves the trim tab in the opposite direction to the movement of the primary control surface. However, at low IAS the servo-tab makes the main control surface less effective. The position of a servo-controlled primary control surface cannot be determined until a positive pressure is applied to the servo-tab by the airflow. Note: Anti-balance Tab: used to increase stick force when they're too light. Balance Tab: moves when the control surface is moved.

content.question: When a jet transport aeroplane takes off with the CG at the forward limit and the trimmable horizontal stabiliser (THS) is positioned at the maximum allowable nose up position for take-off:

options.A: early nose wheel raising will take place.
options.B: rotation will be normal using the normal rotation technique.
options.C: rotation will require a higher than normal stick force.
options.D: there will be a tendency to over-rotate.

key_points: A forward CG position (nose-heavy airplane) results in the greatest nose-down tendency and the aircraft rotates slowly on take-off
The position of the stabiliser for a nose-heavy aeroplane requires nose-up trim
learning.explanation: A forward CG position (nose-heavy airplane) results in the greatest nose-down tendency and the aircraft rotates slowly on take-off. The position of the stabiliser for a nose-heavy aeroplane requires nose-up trim.

content.question: An aircraft with a forward CG has the stabiliser trim set incorrectly for take-off with insufficient nose-up trim. At the correctly determined rotate speed, the normal rotation technique is followed. However, in this situation it is likely that...

options.A: higher-than-usual stick forces will be felt by the pilot and the rate of rotation may be reduced.
options.B: lighter-than-usual stick forces will be felt by the pilot and there maybe an increased possibility of a tail-strike.
options.C: a shorter taketoff distance will be required.
options.D: the aircraft will have an excessive rate of pitch change when rotated.

key_points: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required
A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude
An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch
learning.explanation: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required. A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude. An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch. The CG must always remain within the CG safe envelope to ensure that the airplane remains controllable in all phases of flight. The elevator trim or stabilizer trim setting must be preset to a value for take-off and initial climb that will ensure a minimum stick force during this critical stage of flight. Usually, there is a graph in the airplane performance manual from which the setting appropriate to the total mass and CG position for take-off can be determined. Factors that affect the stabilizer trim position for take-off are: CG position Take-off mass Flap setting In comparison with a correctly balanced airplane during take-off, the position of the stabilizer for a nose-heavy airplane requires nose-up trim from a decreased stabilizer angle of incidence.

content.question: Which of the following is/are required in a fully-powered control system but not required for power-assisted controls?

options.A: Power flying control unit.
options.B: Hydraulic servos.

key_points: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure

Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane
learning.explanation: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure. For a fully powered control system, artificial feel unit is needed. Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane.

content.question: What is a pitching motion?

options.A: It is about the longitudinal axis, related to longitudinal stability.
options.B: It is about the lateral axis, related to longitudinal stability.
options.C: It is about the longitudinal axis, related to lateral stability.
options.D: It is about the lateral axis, related to lateral stability.

key_points: A pitch motion is an up or down movement of the nose of the aircraft about the lateral axis
The pitching motion is being caused by the deflection of the elevator of this aircraft
The longitudinal axis is stabilised by pitching moments
learning.explanation: A pitch motion is an up or down movement of the nose of the aircraft about the lateral axis. The pitching motion is being caused by the deflection of the elevator of this aircraft. The longitudinal axis is stabilised by pitching moments.

content.question: If the nose of an aeroplane yaws left, this causes:

options.A: a roll to the right.
options.B: a decrease in relative airspeed on the right wing.
options.C: a roll to the left.
options.D: an increase in lift on the left wing.

key_points: Roll and yaw motions cannot really be separated from each other, since one triggers the other
Rudder deflection primarily triggers yaw motion and roll is a secondary effect
Yaw causes a slight increase in airspeed over the outer wing of the turn and a decrease in airspeed over the inner wing
learning.explanation: Roll and yaw motions cannot really be separated from each other, since one triggers the other. Rudder deflection primarily triggers yaw motion and roll is a secondary effect. Yaw causes a slight increase in airspeed over the outer wing of the turn and a decrease in airspeed over the inner wing. As a result, the outer wing will generate more lift than the other, introducing a rolling motion. In this case, if an aircraft yaws left, the right wing will travel faster, generating more lift. This will cause a roll to the left.

options.D: when there is a trimmable stabiliser.

key_points: Powered Flying Controls In a fully powered system, aerodynamic loads on aircraft control surfaces are not felt on the cockpit controls (pilot receives no feedback), because there is no physical connection between the pilot's controls and the control surface
In the same way, aerodynamic loads cannot move the controls
This is known as an Irreversible control and requires some form of artificial feel to relay how much force is being applied
learning.explanation: Powered Flying Controls In a fully powered system, aerodynamic loads on aircraft control surfaces are not felt on the cockpit controls (pilot receives no feedback), because there is no physical connection between the pilot's controls and the control surface. In the same way, aerodynamic loads cannot move the controls. This is known as an Irreversible control and requires some form of artificial feel to relay how much force is being applied.

content.question: When comparing a stabiliser trim system with an elevator trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.A: a stabiliser trim is more sensitive to flutter.
options.B: an elevator trim is less suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
options.C: an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.
options.D: an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in airspeed.

key_points: The forces on a jet transport aeroplane are very high in flight
The wing surfaces are large and travel at high speeds, generating lots of lift
A trim tab is an easy solution in general aviation aircraft, as the forces are much smaller and it’s a lot cheaper and lighter than a stabilizer
learning.explanation: The forces on a jet transport aeroplane are very high in flight. The wing surfaces are large and travel at high speeds, generating lots of lift. A trim tab is an easy solution in general aviation aircraft, as the forces are much smaller and it’s a lot cheaper and lighter than a stabilizer. However, the trim tab is not able to withstand the forces at very high speeds and is not powerful enough to generate the loads required for a change in configuration. A stabilizer is powerful enough and is able to cope with larger CG ranges, because the forces required with a CG change will change drastically. Therefore the stabilizer is the best suitable option for transport jet aeroplanes.

content.question: When using aileron-rudder coupling to prevent adverse yaw, when the aircraft is rolled to the right, the left aileron is deflected...

options.A: down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
options.B: up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
options.C: up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.
options.D: down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.

key_points: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases
Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing
These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing
learning.explanation: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases. Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing. These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing. This is adverse yaw, which is particularly significant at low airspeeds because of the large aileron deflection necessary to achieve the same rate of roll as at higher speeds with less deflection. Adverse yaw may be counteracted by any one of the following devices: slot/aileron coupling. spoiler/aileron coupling. frise ailerons. differential aileron deflection. rudder/aileron coupling. The deflection of the ailerons on airplanes fitted with rudder coupling causes the rudder to move an amount proportional to the angular displacement of the aileron and to oppose adverse yaw.

content.question: Before take-off, extra fuel is added aft of the CG, on an airliner with stabiliser trim. After adjusting the trim for take-off, how will the stabiliser move?

options.A: The stabiliser does not move, but the elevator will be deflected downwards.
options.B: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be lowered.
options.C: The trailing edge of the stabiliser will be raised.
options.D: The leading edge of the stabiliser will be raised.

key_points: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls
If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position
This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls
learning.explanation: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls. If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position. This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls. The aircraft may need to be trimmed in pitch as a result of: - changes of speed. - changes of power. - varying CG positions. - changes of configuration. VARIABLE INCIDENCE TAILPLANE The Variable Incidence Horizontal Stabiliser provides pitch trim on most transport category aircraft. Varying the angle of incidence has the same effect as moving the elevator, but is aerodynamically more efficient, particularly at high airspeeds, and can provide a considerable trim range. An actuator near the leading edge varies the angle of incidence of the stabiliser. This normally operates in conjunction with the elevator to produce the least trim drag. The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required. A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the aeroplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude. An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the aeroplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch. The CG must remain within the CG safe envelope at all times to ensure that the aeroplane remains controllable in all phases of flight. The elevator trim or stabiliser trim setting must be preset to a value for take-off and initial climb that will ensure a minimum stick force during this critical stage of flight. In comparison with a correctly balanced aeroplane during take-off, the position of the stabiliser for a nose-light aeroplane requires nose-down trim from an increased stabiliser angle of incidence.

content.question: The pilot's control input in a Fly-By-Wire system is:

options.A: linked by mechanical cables directly to the flight control surface.
options.B: converted into an electrical signal and linked via a computer to the flight control surface.
options.C: linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.
options.D: linked by electrical wires directly to the flight control surface.

key_points: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly by wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. Advantages of fly by wire Weight reduction, as there is no need for the long and heavy control cables this is a big reduction in the weight of the aircraft. Pilot work load is reduced because the pilot is supported by the computers with automated features like auto trim and turn coordination. Flight envelope protection, which can prevent the pilot from pitching up too much beyond the stalling angle of attack. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure Gforces out of the limits. Disadvantages Reliability, as conventional systems might give some indication of an upcoming failure, a fly by wire system can lose a computer would could result in loss of control. This means there is need for redundancy in the form of additional computers and hydraulic systems.

content.question: What does a fully powered system require compared to a partially-powered system?

options.A: Hydraulic servos.
options.B: Servo valve.
options.C: Servo-tab.
options.D: Artificial feel system.

key_points: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure
For a fully powered control system, artificial feel unit is needed
Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane
learning.explanation: FULLY POWERED SYSTEM A fully powered system means that no control force is felt, since the deflection is done solely by hydraulic pressure. For a fully powered control system, artificial feel unit is needed. Without this system it would be easy to aerodynamically over-stress the aeroplane. POWERED-ASSISTED SYSTEM A power-assisted system is designed so that a part of the control force is felt by the pilot (the rest is done by hydraulic power).

content.question: In general, control forces are reduced by:

options.A: a horn balance, servo tab and spring tab.
options.B: a balance tab, forward shift of the CG and a servo tab.
options.C: a servo tab, spring tab and mass balancing.
options.D: mass balancing, a trim tab and spring tab.

key_points: The primary function of any aerodynamic control surface balancing method is to reduce the force required to operate the control
The most common methods employed to achieve this aim and reduce the maneuver stick force are: the hinge balance
the horn balance
learning.explanation: The primary function of any aerodynamic control surface balancing method is to reduce the force required to operate the control. The most common methods employed to achieve this aim and reduce the maneuver stick force are: the hinge balance. the horn balance. the internal balance (sealed chamber). the balance tab. the spring tab. the servo-tab. Note: "mass balance" is incorrect as it is used to reduce flutter and not stick forces.

content.question: As the CG of an aircraft moves forward from the neutral point, the amount of elevator deflection required to control the aircraft...

options.A: decreases and then increases.
options.B: remains the same.
options.C: increases.
options.D: decreases.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)
This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating
As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. In this case, if an aircraft is very stable (forward CG), the elevator will have to produce a bigger moment to move the pitch and thus requires a larger deflection

content.question: In a power-assisted flight control system, most of the force is provided by the…

options.A: servo valve.
options.B: hydraulic system.
options.C: pilot.
options.D: servo tab.

key_points: If the required assistance for the pilot to move the controls cannot be provided by the preceding types of aerodynamic balance, then power assisted, or fully powered controls must be used
The aerodynamic force on the controls will depend on the area of the control surface, its angular displacement, and the IAS
For large and fast aircraft, the resulting aerodynamic force can give hinge moments / stick forces which are too high for easy operation of the controls
learning.explanation: If the required assistance for the pilot to move the controls cannot be provided by the preceding types of aerodynamic balance, then power assisted, or fully powered controls must be used. The aerodynamic force on the controls will depend on the area of the control surface, its angular displacement, and the IAS. For large and fast aircraft, the resulting aerodynamic force can give hinge moments / stick forces which are too high for easy operation of the controls. The pilot will require assistance to move the controls in these conditions, and this can be done either by using (hydraulic) powered flying controls or by using some form of aerodynamic balance.

content.question: In comparison to elevator deflection, all-flying tailplanes require (1) _____ force to change the aircraft's pitch attitude and cause (2) _____ drag.

options.A: (1) more; (2) more
options.B: (1) more; (2) less
options.C: (1) less; (2) less
options.D: (1) less; (2) more

key_points: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions
They also need large control surfaces to be able to control such large aircraft
For these reasons, elevators are often not enough on their own to provide all the pitch trim and pitch control required
learning.explanation: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions. They also need large control surfaces to be able to control such large aircraft. For these reasons, elevators are often not enough on their own to provide all the pitch trim and pitch control required. Some aircraft use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser and elevators, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this. Some aircraft go even further than this, and have something known as an "all moving tailplane", or "all-flying tailplane", and is also known as a "slab tail". This has no elevator surface at the back, and combines the trim and control inputs into a single movement that the whole tail makes. This is more efficient than using elevators only, as it is a large (full wing) surface making a small change, rather than smaller elevators making a large change, and this not only causes a lot less aerodynamic drag, but also requires less force from the aircraft's hydraulic systems. The reason less force is required to move the all-flying tailplane than elevators is because elevators are hinged at the front, whereas "slab tails" rotate around a point closer to the middle, and therefore the front of the tail helps the movement somewhat. Also, a much smaller movement is required, which does not "fight" the airflow as much, like an elevator does. This is why they may also be used on light aircraft to provide "lighter" stick forces, but on larger aircraft, the hydraulics are doing all the hard work anyway.

content.question: The pilots prepare and trim the aircraft for take-off, setting the trim for a CG position at 24% of the MAC. But due to an error, the real position of the CG is at 12% of the MAC. What could this cause?

options.A: The length of the runway may not be sufficient to take-off.
options.B: Large stick forces are required to achieve rotation.
options.C: Risk of over rotation that can lead to a tail strike.
options.D: Reduced climb performance after take-off.

key_points: When the CG is located further forward than intended, it shifts the aircraft's balance towards the nose
In this case, during takeoff, the aircraft would tend to have a tendency to pitch down, making it harder to rotate and lift off the runway
The pilots would need to apply significant backpressure on the control stick to raise the nose and achieve the desired rotation angle
learning.explanation: When the CG is located further forward than intended, it shifts the aircraft's balance towards the nose. In this case, during takeoff, the aircraft would tend to have a tendency to pitch down, making it harder to rotate and lift off the runway. The pilots would need to apply significant backpressure on the control stick to raise the nose and achieve the desired rotation angle. This would result in large stick forces being required to initiate the rotation. The risk of over rotation and tail strike (option c) would not be a concern in this scenario since the CG is forward rather than aft. The other options, a) and d), are not directly affected by the CG position and are not applicable in this situation. Therefore, if the actual CG position is at 12% (as opposed to 24%) of the MAC, the correct answer would be b) Large stick forces are required to achieve rotation.

content.question: A trim tab is an adjustable surface which can reduce the moment at the hinge line of the main control surface to zero. It can achieve this because its lift force...

options.A: is set far from the hinge line of the main control surface.
options.B: can be deflected through a larger angle compared to the main control surface.
options.C: is controlled from the cockpit just like the main control surface.
options.D: is set close to the hinge line of the main control surface.

key_points: Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection
However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer
There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed
learning.explanation: Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection. However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer. There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed. The variable trim tabs may be manually or electrically controlled. If manually controlled, then trim wheels located on the center console are used. For the elevator trim if the tab is deflected up the cockpit indication is nose-down and if the trim tab is deflected down the cockpit indication is nose-up. To remain in trim and maintain level flight following a deceleration the trimmer control is moved to give a nose-up movement that causes the trim tab to move down, which makes the elevator move up. This does not affect the static longitudinal stability. The moment required to move the primary control surface to the required position (MM) is equal to the force (FM) multiplied by the length of the arm (Am) from the hinge of the elevator to the center of pressure of the elevator main control surface. The same moment can be applied to the elevators by a smaller force (FT) in the opposite direction generated by a trim tab multiplied by the longer arm distance (AT) from the center of pressure of the trim tab to the elevator hinge-line. In other words, (FM × AM) = (FT × AT). The trim tab thereby does the work required to maintain the elevator out of the neutral position and there is no need for any force from the pilot’s controls.

content.question: Generally, ailerons are fitted towards the wing-tips. However, some aeroplanes are fitted with outboard and inboard ailerons. At high flight speeds only the inboard ailerons are used, this is done to...

options.A: reduce the rolling moments which might generate excessive bending forces at their wing root if the outboard ailerons were to be used.
options.B: ensure that the wing does NOT twist through aero elastic effects which would modify the local angle of attack and generate roll reversal.
options.C: reduce the effects of adverse yaw which are greater when using outboard ailerons.
options.D: increase flight control redundancy in the aeroplane’s roll control should the outboard aileron system fail.

key_points: AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift
The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment
INBOARD AILERONS Ailerons are normally situated at the wing tips to give the greatest rolling moment for the force produced
learning.explanation: AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift. The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment. INBOARD AILERONS Ailerons are normally situated at the wing tips to give the greatest rolling moment for the force produced. However, this means they are also able to generate the maximum twisting loads on the wing. For instance, a down-going aileron will twist the wing tip and decrease wing tip incidence. The wing is not a rigid structure and any twist will cause a decrease of aileron effectiveness. As IAS increases, a down-going aileron will give more wing twist (decreased wing tip incidence). Eventually, an IAS will be reached at which the decrease in tip incidence will give a larger downforce than the upforce produced by the aileron. This is called high speed “aileron reversal”; the wing will go down, rather than up as the pilot intended. To reduce this effect, the ailerons could be mounted further inboard. Unfortunately, this would reduce aileron effectiveness at low speed. Alternatively, two sets of ailerons may be fitted: one set at the wing tips for use only at low speeds when the forces involved are low, and one set inboard for use at high speeds when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion. Outboard (low speed) ailerons are “locked-out” as the flaps retract. At low speed both sets of ailerons work, but at high speed only the inboard ailerons respond to control input.

content.question: The aircraft yaws to the left. This might occur because:

options.A: You roll to the right.
options.B: You press the right pedal.
options.C: You roll the left.
options.D: There is increased lift in the right wing.

key_points: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn
As you roll to the right, your airplane may initially yaw to the left
When you roll your airplane to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn. As you roll to the right, your airplane may initially yaw to the left. When you roll your airplane to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down. The right aileron creates less lift and less drag than the aileron that is lowered. The aileron angled downward - the left aileron - produces more drag and more lift, initially yawing the airplane in the opposite direction of your roll.

content.question: A jet transport aircraft is on short final approach when a vehicle enters the runway and they have to go-around. Upon going around, the crew notices that the stabiliser trim has jammed. How will this affect controllability?

options.A: The aircraft will NOT be able to go around, and the crew must land.
options.B: The aircraft will respond less to the elevator in the opposite sense.
options.C: The aircraft's nose will tend to rise as the aircraft accelerates.
options.D: The aircraft's nose will tend to lower as the aircraft accelerates.

key_points: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions

They often use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this (some aircraft have a "slab tail" design where the elevator and trim are both done by an all-moving tailplane)
If this stabiliser becomes jammed, then the aircraft will remain trimmed for a particular configuration/speed, and can cause serious problems when flying in other configurations/speeds
learning.explanation: Modern jet transport aircraft have such a large speed range (often from around 100-140 kts up to 300+ knots IAS), that they need a huge trim range, to be able to fly in all those different trim conditions. They often use a variable incidence horizontal stabiliser, which just means that the whole tailplane moves in order to trim the aircraft and the elevators are a control surface on the back of this (some aircraft have a "slab tail" design where the elevator and trim are both done by an all-moving tailplane). If this stabiliser becomes jammed, then the aircraft will remain trimmed for a particular configuration/speed, and can cause serious problems when flying in other configurations/speeds. In this case, the pilot is trimmed for a low speed (forget flap settings for now because they make things overly complicated but don't change the answer), which means being trimmed for a high angle of attack. In reality, the basis behind trimming is actually quite complicated, but in essence, we trim to balance the aircraft at a particular angle of attack, which equates to a speed (there are a lot of assumptions in that statement but it's fine for this question). When we accelerate from that speed, the aircraft will provide too much lift and pitch up naturally, this is where we would usually begin to trim down to decrease the angle of attack, but without a working trimmer, we have to hold it on the elevator control whilst out of the trimmed condition. Without an elevator, the aircraft will continue to pitch up until it stops accelerating. If there isn't a separate elevator, then the aircraft will have to be trimmed with speed using thrust, faster makes it pitch up, slower makes it pitch down. The aircraft will attempt to hold the same angle of attack, which loosely equates to a speed. It can be flown like this, but it would not be easy. This question seems like there is a separate trimmer to the elevator, so that should not be necessary.

content.question: An aeroplane has a servo tab controlled elevator. What will happen if the elevator jams during flight?

options.A: The servo tab now works as a negative trim tab.
options.B: Pitch control sense is reversed.
options.C: Pitch control is lost.
options.D: The pitch control forces double.

key_points: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable
To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function
The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column
learning.explanation: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable. To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function. The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column. There is no direct link between the control column and the primary control surface. The function and operation of the servo-tab is the same as the balance tab and moves the trim tab in the opposite direction to the movement of the primary control surface. However, at low IAS the servo-tab makes the main control surface less effective. The position of a servo-controlled primary control surface cannot be determined until a positive pressure is applied to the servo-tab by the airflow. In flight, if a servo-controlled elevator jams the servo-tab reverses the direction of the pitch control input, because the elevator becomes part of the fixed horizontal stabilizer and the servo-tab now acts as a small elevator because despite its small size it has a longer moment arm than the elevator and consequently generates a large moment. Under normal circumstances an up servo-tab position would drive the elevator to a downward deflection causing the airplane’s nose to go down, but if the elevator is fixed the servo-tab in an up position will cause the airplane’s nose to move up.

content.question: A given aileron deflection affects...

options.A: bank angle and is dependent on TAS
options.B: bank angle and is dependent on IAS
options.C: roll rate and is dependent on TAS
