key_points: Flutter is an oscillation of the control surface which can occur due to the bending and twisting of the structure under load
If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line
The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure
learning.explanation: Flutter is an oscillation of the control surface which can occur due to the bending and twisting of the structure under load. If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line. The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure. Flutter involves: - aerodynamic forces. - inertia forces. - the elastic properties of a surface. An aircraft is subject to many aerodynamic excitations (gusts, control inputs, etc.) and the aerodynamic forces at various speeds have characteristic properties for rate of change of force and moment. The interaction of the aerofoil mass and the aerodynamic load imposed on the aerofoil causes distortion by bending and torsion of the structure that can result in a violent vibration in the resonance frequency, which if excessive can cause structural failure. This is ‘flutter’ and the aeroelastic coupling will affect its characteristics. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. CONTROL SURFACE FLUTTER Control surface flutter can develop as a result of an oscillation of the control surface coupled with an oscillation in bending or twisting of the wing, tailplane or fin. A control surface oscillation can result from backlash (free play) in the control system or from a disturbance (gust). MASS BALANCE Flutter may be prevented by adding weight to the control surface in front of the hinge line. This brings the centre of gravity of the control forward to a position on, or slightly in front of the hinge, but always to the point required by the designers. This reduces the inertia moments about the hinge and prevents flutter developing.

content.question: A light aircraft with mechanical flight controls occasionally experiences uncomfortable pitch oscillations after encountering normal turbulence. The pilot does not note any such oscillations when cruising in smooth air at normal cruising speed, but does notice some excessive slack or play in the elevator linkages after the flight. What potential hazards could this situation cause if not addressed by maintenance?

options.A: This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens.
options.B: A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe.
options.C: The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight.
options.D: Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation.

key_points: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question
The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities
We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question. The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities. We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct or not. Authority Reported Answer Hungary Not C Poland B Austro Not D We would say if your country is not Hungary or Poland, go for C. FLUTTER Flutter occurs because a wing (or other aerodynamic surface) is not perfectly stiff, and will bend and twist under high aerodynamic loads. The control surfaces can cause a cyclic movement where the wing moves but the control surface "lags behind", creating an even larger force on the wing. The wing will then do the same thing in the opposite direction, and at certain frequencies can build up to a large, short term oscillation that can cause significant damage ton the aircraft. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. A control surface oscillation can also be intensified or created by any slack (free play) in the control lines, where the control surface can move freely without pilot input. This means that small disturbances such as turbulence could cause un-commanded control surface movements, which then begin a period of flutter, as eluded to in the question. To go through the options: "This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens." It is not a phugoid type oscillation being described, as a phugoid has a greater time period than this short interval flutter. "A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe." The control surface is not necessarily poorly balanced; the cause of the flutter is the free play in the control lines, so we would say this is not correct. However, the rest of the option is correct, so it's not far off. "The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight." We believe this is fully correct. The free play in the control lines can cause this kind of response. "Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation." For a while, the Polish ULC considered this to be correct (we believe), but recent feedback indicates they no longer do. The short period motion doesn't really cause large speed changes (that would be a phugoid) and therefore it is not very likely to cause a stall or overspeed situation.

content.question:
The VA speed of a light aircraft is 133 kt. Determine the aircraft's limit load factor, given the following information from the airspeed indicator.
Green arc: 73 kt - 177 kt
White arc: 53 kt - 104 kt
VNE: 185 kt

options.D: Can't be calculated.

key_points: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe
VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling
If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling
learning.explanation: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe. VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling. If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling. We can therefore use VA in calculations, as it is the stall speed of an aircraft at it's limit load factor. Stall speed calculations are based on the lift force required by the wings, and that varies with weight and load factor (G-force). The higher the weight, or the higher the load factor, the higher airspeed that is required (more airflow makes the wing able to produce greater forces before stalling). For load factor, the formula is: New VS = VS(1G) x sqrt(load factor) Where VS(1G) is the stall speed at 1G (straight level flight) So for the manoeuvring speed VA = VS(1G) x sqrt(limit load factor) We can then re-arrange this to find the limit load factor if we know the VA and the VS(1G) (which we do in this question). The VS(1G) is given in the question as the bottom of the green arc. (VA / VS(1G))2 = limit load factor Limit load factor = (133/73)2 = 3.3 G

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the speeds VMO and VC?

options.A: VMO must be equal to VC.
options.B: VMO must be equal to or greater than VC.
options.C: VMO must NOT be greater than VC.
options.D: VMO must NOT be greater than 0.8 x VC.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.02.01.05: Describe the relationship between VMO or VNE and VC. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations.

content.question: The lift coefficient (CL) of an aeroplane in steady horizontal flight is 0.35. An increase in angle of attack of 1 degree would increase CL by 0.079. If a vertical gust instantly changes the angle of attack by 2 degrees, the load factor will be:

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. It can be defined by: load factor(n) = (Lift(L))/(Weight(W)) In straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, thus n = 1. In this exercise, the increment in CL from a gust will be of 0.079 for every degree of angle of attack impacted by the gust. We also know that the aircraft encounters a gust which increases its angle of attack by 2°. In straight and level flight n = 1 or: n = 0.35/0.35 A 2° increase in angle of attack, 2*0.079 = 0.158 Will give an increment of 0.45 in the CL: 0.35+0.158 = 0.508 A gust which increases the angle of attack by 2° will increase the load factor to: n = 0.508/0.35 ≈ 1.45 g

learning.explanation: This is a poorly worded question. In straight and level flight, the aircraft experiences a load factor of 1 (1 g). The aircraft would be able to withstand a positive normal acceleration of 0.3 g, which totals the buffet margin of 1.3 g. “performs a level turn with 45 of bank without experiencing low speed buffet” Incorrect. Load factor = 1 /cos (bank angle) Load factor = 1 / cos (45º) = 1.41 g 1.41 g exceeds the buffet margin (1.3 g).

content.question:
Which of these statements about the gust load factor on an aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
I. When the mass decreases, the gust load factor increases.
II. When the altitude increases, the gust load factor increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. The load factor deriving from a gust is determined by the magnitude of the vertical velocity of the gust and the forward speed of the airplane. High wing loading reduces the ‘g’ increment in a gust. This is because the lift increment produced is a smaller proportion of the original lift force for the more heavily loaded aircraft. For a given TAS and gust speed, the increase of lift will be proportional to the wing area. Therefore, the increase in load factor is inversely proportional to the wing loading. WingLoading = Weight/(WingArea) Decreasing mass, decreases wing loading which increases load factor. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. With increasing altitude, density decreases and any aerodynamic force resulting from a gust will be smaller. Thus, when comparing two aircraft flying at different altitudes, the one flying in thinner air (higher altitude) will experience a decreased increment in load factor following a gust. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: What speed will be limiting with a descent at constant mach?

options.A: MMO
options.B: VMO
options.C: VS
options.D: VNE

key_points: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high
At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder
Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level
learning.explanation: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high. At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder. Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level. The result of this is that, as you climb, the maximum speed is controlled at low level by CAS and VMO, and at altitude you reach your limiting Mach number MMO, before you reach VMO and therefore your maximum speed is controlled by MMO. In the descent the reverse is true. Your maximum speed is controlled by MMO first, and then by VMO at lower altitudes. Alternatively, LSS increases during the descent, due to the rising temperature. Therefore, TAS must increase during descent to maintain constant Mach No. IAS is also increasing and will eventually reach its limit. VMO ("max operating") is the term for the maximum certified IAS. NOTE: You can also advice the ECTM lines to show that IAS increases with constant Mach.

learning.explanation: Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25. CS-23 covers "small aircraft". CS-23 also covers commuter category aircraft up to 8618 kg MTOW and a MOPSC of 19 or fewer. This means that there are CS-23 aircraft with an MTOW above 5670 kg. CS-25 covers "large aircraft". Specifically, "turbine powered Large Aeroplanes". This includes turboprop aircraft as well as turbojet/turbofan (jet aircraft). There is a difference between the limiting flight airspeeds, VNE and VMO/MMO. Some aircraft (usually smaller, slower aircraft) use VNE - the never exceed speed, and a corresponding VNO, the normal operating speed, which should only be exceeded in smooth air (bottom of the yellow arc). Larger/faster aircraft use VMO/MMO - the maximum operating speed/maximum operating Mach number. This is calculated a little differently to VNE, and is a speed that should not be exceeded during normal operations. An aircraft either has VNE or VMO/MMO, never both. If an aircraft uses VMO, it will also have a corresponding MMO, but this is not mentioned in this question CS-23 aircraft mostly use VNE, but turbine powered aeroplanes and those with a particular design dive speed instead use a VMO/MMO (CS 23.1505). Therefore, CS-23 aircraft can use either VNE or VMO/MMO, depending on the particular aircraft. CS-25 aircraft only use VMO/MMO.

The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop

Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

Fixed pitch propellers are most efficient at a certain TAS value (for a certain RPM - which we are assuming), as this is where the angle of attack of the incoming airflow is the optimum angle of attack (similar to how a wing has an optimum angle of attack), where the lift to drag ratio is highest, to provide the most thrust for the least backwards torque on the engine. This can severely limit the cruise speed of aircraft with fixed pitch props, and therefore, aircraft are equipped with different pitch props based on their expected use-cases. slow training aircraft are equipped with fine pitch "climb" propellers and cruise focussed aircraft are equipped with coarser "cruise" propellers, so they are most capable in their expected speed range. Constant speed (variable pitch) propellers do not have the same disadvantages, as they can change their blade angle to have a much greater band of maximum efficiency. They will therefore be fine for take-off and low speeds, but the constant speed unit will increase the blade angle to keep it more efficient at higher true airspeeds. Therefore, when brakes are released on take-off, the propeller starts getting more efficient as it accelerates, until the propeller angle of attack reaches its optimum, and then after that, the propeller can be made to stay at optimum efficiency after this, in the climb and up to a much higher cruise TAS. learning.explanation: Solidity is the ratio of the propeller blade's frontal area to the propeller disc area. content.question:
An historical single-engine aeroplane which has a left-hand rotating propeller (ANTI-CLOCKWISE from the pilot's perspective) is on final approach, when the pilot decides to perform a go-around, applying full THRUST and a large PITCH-UP. Which of the following would occur:
1. Spiralling slipstream generates a yaw to the left.
2. Torque reaction makes the aircraft roll to the right.
3. Gyroscopic precession generates a yaw to the right
4. Asymmetric blade makes the aircraft yaw to the right.

options.B: 2 and 4.
options.C: 1 and 2.
options.D: 3 and 4.

key_points: Note: This question was generated based on feedback which was posted on question 813311

Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario
learning.explanation: Note: This question was generated based on feedback which was posted on question 813311. Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. 1. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. Statement 1 is incorrect. 2. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). Statement 1 is correct. 3. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect. 4. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Statement 4 is correct.

This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds
This facility not only improves the propeller efficiency but also decreases the fuel consumption
learning.explanation: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes. This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds. This facility not only improves the propeller efficiency but also decreases the fuel consumption. The pitch angle or blade angle of a constant-speed propeller (fixe RPM) increases (or coarsens) with increasing TAS. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. Propeller efficiency improves with increased TAS; however, it is limited to that blade angle beyond which the propeller will no longer produce any thrust.

content.question: Consider a constant speed propeller. Which of the following forces or moments tend to decrease the pitch angle of the propeller blades (move them towards fine pitch)?

options.A: The blade pitch angle cannot be changed by any forces or moments.
options.B: The centrifugal twisting (turning) moment.
options.C: The aerodynamic twisting moment.
options.D: The thrust bending force.

key_points: This is not too often mentioned in the ATPL exams, and can get quite complicated very quickly if you dig too far, but we will keep it simple

Naturally, there are a few different forces acting on a propeller blade: Torque force - acting against the direction of rotation (against the engine torque) Thrust force - acting in the direction of flight (perpendicular to the plane of rotation)
(this can be a negative force when windmilling or providing reverse thrust)
learning.explanation: This is not too often mentioned in the ATPL exams, and can get quite complicated very quickly if you dig too far, but we will keep it simple. Naturally, there are a few different forces acting on a propeller blade: Torque force - acting against the direction of rotation (against the engine torque) Thrust force - acting in the direction of flight (perpendicular to the plane of rotation). (this can be a negative force when windmilling or providing reverse thrust). There are also a few different moments (bending/twisting forces on the propeller blades) Torque bending force - causing the tips to lag behind the blade hubs due to the torque force. Thrust bending force - bending the edges of the propeller disc in the direction of flight due to the thrust force. Centrifugal twisting moment (CTM) - twisting the propeller to the "fine" direction due to the centrifugal pulling force on the blade (trying to flatten the blade onto the plane of rotation). Aerodynamic twisting moment (ATM) - twisting the propeller to the "coarse" direction (unless windmilling) due to the location of the centre of pressure ahead of the point of rotation. The torque bending moment and thrust bending force are not usually asked in the exams, but the CTM and ATMs are a larger part of the syllabus (though still very rare). Between the CTM and the ATM, they work in opposite directions and CTM is stronger (except when the propeller is windmilling when they work in the same direction (both to "fine")). In this case, the CTM (Centrifugal Twisting Moment) is the correct answer as it tries to decrease the blade pitch angle (make the blade more fine).

content.question: What happens if a pilot flying a clockwise rotating propeller performs a go around?

options.A: Asymmetric thrust is generated, leading to an increased left yaw.
options.B: Asymmetric thrust is generated, leading to an increased right yaw.
options.C: Symmetrical thrust is generated, leading to an increased right yaw.
options.D: Symmetrical thrust is generated, leading to an increased left yaw.

key_points: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped as small wings

As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: The down-going blade (viewed from the cockpit) will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust
This then means that the down-swinging (right) blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade
learning.explanation: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped as small wings. As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: The down-going blade (viewed from the cockpit) will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust. This then means that the down-swinging (right) blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade. For this reason, the thrust line will be displaced to the right of the engine centre line. If both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine. This difference in thrust will give a yawing moment to the left with a clockwise rotating propeller in a nose-up attitude. This effect will be greatest at full power and low airspeed.

content.question: You are the pilot flying of a single engine tailwheel aircraft with a strong propeller turning right on a wet grass runway. During acceleration for take-off, you are forced to use considerable right rudder to keep the aircraft straight. This is because during the early part of the take-off run the propeller produces…

options.A: slipstream effect before the tail is lifted, and asymmetric blade effect after the tail is lifted.
options.B: gyroscopic precession before the tail is lifted, and slipstream effect after the tail is lifted.
options.C: asymmetric blade effect before the tail is lifted, and gyroscopic precession as the tail is lifted.
options.D: gyroscopic precession as the tail is lifted, and asymmetric blade effect only after the tail is lifted.

key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT (figure 1) This effect occurs when the axis of rotation of the propeller is inclined to the direction of flight
For example, when the tail wheel on a tail-dragger type aircraft is in contact with the ground, its longitudinal axis inclines above the horizontal
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT (figure 1) This effect occurs when the axis of rotation of the propeller is inclined to the direction of flight. For example, when the tail wheel on a tail-dragger type aircraft is in contact with the ground, its longitudinal axis inclines above the horizontal. This causes the down-going blade to have a greater effective angle of attack than the up-going blade, thus developing greater thrust. The thrust asymmetry between the two blades causes the aircraft to yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT (figure 2) A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down.

When the airplane is moving it comprises two parts, the angle of attack and the helix angle, but when it is stationary the blade angle is equal to the angle of attack

learning.explanation: The Blade Angle Sometimes called the pitch angle, is the angle subtended between the plane of rotation and the chord line of the propeller blade, which may be fixed or variable. When the airplane is moving it comprises two parts, the angle of attack and the helix angle, but when it is stationary the blade angle is equal to the angle of attack. The Helix Angle The angle that the actual path of the propeller makes to the plane of rotation. Angle of Attack The path of the propeller through the air determines the direction of the relative airflow. The angle between the blade chord and the relative airflow is the angle of attack (α). The angle of attack (α) is the result of propeller rotational velocity (RPM) and aircraft forward velocity (TAS).

content.question: An airplane with a tricycle undercarriage, a single high-power turbine engine, and a propeller rotating clockwise (from the pilot's perspective) is taking off with full power from a wet grass runway. The pilot fails to properly control the aircraft's direction during the takeoff roll, causing the plane to swerve off to the left side of the runway before rotation. Which of the following propeller forces and effects contributed to this loss of control?

options.A: Gyroscopic precession
options.B: Spiral slipstream
options.C: Asymmetric blade effect
options.D: Propeller drag

key_points: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream

At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface
When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis
learning.explanation: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. On clockwise-rotating propellers, the spiralling slipstream causes a yawing moment to the left. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis. Note: Asymmetric blade effect and gyroscopic precession occur during rotation; since this question specifies the period before rotation, these factors are not correct.

content.question: A multi-engined piston aeroplane is in the cruise at FL210 flying over the Alps when one propeller suffers a problem with the anti-icing system and icing starts to build up on one of the propellers. Which of the following is a possible hazard of propeller icing?

options.A: Reduced propeller efficiency means that the aircraft can NOT maintain cruising altitude.
options.B: The propeller mass becomes severely imbalanced and results in damages to the propeller.
options.C: Reduced thrust available means that the aircraft can NOT remain safely airborne.
options.D: Ice breaking off the propeller and damaging the landing gear wheels.

key_points: Ice contamination on the propeller has the same effect as ice on the wings, in that both reduce the efficiency of the aerofoils
Leading edge ice on the propeller reduces the generated thrust in the same way the lift of the wing is reduced
Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust
learning.explanation: Ice contamination on the propeller has the same effect as ice on the wings, in that both reduce the efficiency of the aerofoils. Leading edge ice on the propeller reduces the generated thrust in the same way the lift of the wing is reduced. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. In addition, the weight of the ice increases the aircraft weight and therefore the lift required. If ice builds on an unprotected propeller, thrust reduces and you might not be able to climb out of the icing conditions or maintain the altitude. The greatest quantity of ice normally collects on the spinner and inner radius of the propeller. The estimated propeller efficiency loss is on the order of 15%-20%.

content.question: Which type of force tends to decrease the angle of attack on a propeller (fixed or variable pitch)?

options.A: Aerodynamic force.
options.B: Centrifugal force.
options.C: No forces reduce the blade angle of attack.
options.D: Centripetal force.

key_points: The centrifugal force to which a rotating propeller is subject creates tensile stress at the blade root and a torque across the chord of the blade, about the pitch-change axis
The centrifugal force (CF) acting along a radial from the propeller hub is divided into components parallel to the pitch-change axis and at right angles to that axis

Because in normal flight the propeller blade has a positive angle of attack the blade leading edge is above the blade trailing edge, which creates a twisting moment about the pitch-change axis (the blade’s longitudinal axis) attempting to bring the blade mass in line with the plane of rotation
learning.explanation: The centrifugal force to which a rotating propeller is subject creates tensile stress at the blade root and a torque across the chord of the blade, about the pitch-change axis. The centrifugal force (CF) acting along a radial from the propeller hub is divided into components parallel to the pitch-change axis and at right angles to that axis. Because in normal flight the propeller blade has a positive angle of attack the blade leading edge is above the blade trailing edge, which creates a twisting moment about the pitch-change axis (the blade’s longitudinal axis) attempting to bring the blade mass in line with the plane of rotation. The Centrifugal Twisting Moment tends to decrease the blade angle of attack, thereby ‘fining’ the pitch. Therefore, the fitted pitch-change mechanism requires little energy to reduce the blade angle but needs a lot more effort to increase the blade angle, i.e. coarsen the propeller pitch.

content.question: How does icing affect a propeller?

options.A: Decrease thrust.
options.B: Decrease thrust due to increase AoA.
options.C: Increases thrust.
options.D: Due to the high speed of the propeller the ice will melt away and don’t affect the thrust.

key_points: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack
Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust
As the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given RPM and blade angle
learning.explanation: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. As the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given RPM and blade angle. Since ice on the propeller blades reduces the available thrust, extra power may be required from the engine to overcome the increased drag, decreasing propeller efficiency. Note: Propeller icing can be expected to reduce propeller efficiency by up to 10% normally, but could up to 20% in very severe icing. Propeller icing occurs on the leading edge, but is least at the tip of the blade, where the high rotational speed tends to shed the ice more easily.

key_points: For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails

That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event
During a crosswind take-off an airplane tends to weathercock into wind
learning.explanation: For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails. That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event. During a crosswind take-off an airplane tends to weathercock into wind. Because of this the failure of the outboard engine on the windward side of the airplane is the most difficult to counteract and is, therefore, the critical engine for jet-propelled aircraft. For propeller-driven airplanes the direction of propeller rotation determines the critical engine. Viewed from behind, a clockwise rotation dictates that the outboard left engine is critical.

key_points: Most traditional twin-engine aircraft have clockwise-rotating propellers when viewed from behind

The primary advantage lies in balancing torque and P-factor effects, ensuring there is no critical engine in the event of failure. key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Torque reaction To analyze these effects, consider a right-handed propeller, which rotates clockwise as viewed from the cockpit
This occurs because the air resists the motion of the propeller
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Torque reaction To analyze these effects, consider a right-handed propeller, which rotates clockwise as viewed from the cockpit. content.question: On a multi-engine propeller aircraft, the synchro phasor measures...

options.A: Revolutions per Minute (RPM)
options.B: Blade angle of attack (AoA)
options.C: Propeller Torque (N-m)
options.D: Frequency (Hz)

key_points: In a multi-engine propeller aircraft, the synchro phasor is a device used to measure and display the relative phase relationship between the propellers of different engines
It helps ensure that the propellers on all engines are synchronized and operating in harmony
The synchro phasor primarily measures the revolutions per minute (RPM) of each propeller
learning.explanation: In a multi-engine propeller aircraft, the synchro phasor is a device used to measure and display the relative phase relationship between the propellers of different engines. It helps ensure that the propellers on all engines are synchronized and operating in harmony. The synchro phasor primarily measures the revolutions per minute (RPM) of each propeller. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiralling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT (figure 2) A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down.

key_points: The propeller shaft inclines upwards due to the angle of attack of the airplane

This results in the down-going (right) blade generating slightly more thrust
learning.explanation: The propeller shaft inclines upwards due to the angle of attack of the airplane. Consequently, the down-going propeller blade experiences a greater effective angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, owing to a slight relative forward movement. This results in the down-going (right) blade generating slightly more thrust. As a consequence, the line of thrust shifts right of the propeller cone. Consequently, the left thrust arm is smaller than the right thrust arm. The difference in thrust on both sides of the propeller disc induces a yawing moment to the left when the propeller rotates clockwise in a nose-up attitude. This phenomenon, known as asymmetric blade effect or P-factor, is most pronounced at full power and low airspeed, primarily due to the high angle of attack experienced during takeoff, climb, and go-around maneuvers. Note: The gyroscopic precession of the propeller results in a force applied perpendicular to the plane of rotation appearing to act 90° in the direction of rotation. When the aircraft turns left, a force is applied to the propeller on the right-hand side when viewed from behind. This force, appearing 90° later in this scenario, would be at the bottom of the propeller, causing the aircraft to pitch up.

As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

content.question: Why is a propeller blade twisted from root to tip?

options.B: To ensure that the tip produces most thrust.

key_points: As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time
The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i
e
learning.explanation: As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time. The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i.e. not forwards speed). The forwards speed of airflow into the propeller is the same for all sections of the blade, but the lateral speed of the propeller varies massively along the length of the blade. This means the angle of the oncoming airflow is very different for the propeller tip as for the root (near the hub). For this reason, the propeller blade is twisted very significantly between the root and the tip, in order to make sure that the angle of attack remains roughly constant along the length of the blade. The root of the propeller has a very large blade angle and the tip has a much smaller blade angle, but - at the optimum RPM and forwards speed (TAS) - the angle of attack of the whole propeller should be close to the optimum angle of attack. As for the other options, neither the root nor the tip produces most thrust, it is maximum around 75% radius. The root is travelling too slowly to produce much thrust and tip losses means that the thrust drops off in that region also.

learning.explanation: The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases. Assuming that propeller RPM and blade pitch angle remains constant, at a low speed the angle of attack will be large, giving a lot of thrust. Alpha will reduce with increasing speed and at about 4 degrees the blade will be operating at its best lift/drag ratio, i.e. the propeller is achieving its highest efficiency. Higher speeds (maybe in a dive) will reduce the blade angle of attack to its zero lift value of about minus 4 degrees. At this point, the propeller will be producing zero thrust. That means that the maximum thrust produced by a propeller driven aircraft, also occurs at zero forward airspeed and reduces with forward speed. A fixed propeller can only have one optimum combination of forward airspeed and engine RPM and only one optimum propeller efficiency. At all other combinations it operates less efficiently. key_points: To prevent the propeller from ‘windmilling’, the propeller blade of a failed engine is rotated from the fine-pitch stop, through the coarse-pitch stop, to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; this is called ‘feathering’ the propeller
It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because this is the best compromise for the whole blade length when accounting for the blade twist

The purpose of this is to reduce drag from the propeller, as the assumption is that the engine has failed in flight, and therefore maximising thrust and reducing drag is necessary to maintain the best possible climb performance
learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘windmilling’, the propeller blade of a failed engine is rotated from the fine-pitch stop, through the coarse-pitch stop, to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; this is called ‘feathering’ the propeller. It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because this is the best compromise for the whole blade length when accounting for the blade twist. The purpose of this is to reduce drag from the propeller, as the assumption is that the engine has failed in flight, and therefore maximising thrust and reducing drag is necessary to maintain the best possible climb performance. By turning the propeller to the feathered position, there is the minimum frontal area to produce drag, and the propeller is not inclined to rotate, which is the "windmilling" tendency that propellers have: Not only is this bad for drag, it is also bad for continuing to turn the engine and potentially causing further damage or spreading a possible fire, etc. For a single-engine airplane, feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance due to lower drag, however, having the blade at a fine pitch setting would be better if a restart is to be attempted. As such, feathering the propeller may be used to increase the gliding range/endurance, if it is available. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag improves climb performance, but is also good for reducing the amount of yaw. As the drag of the failed engine propeller acts in the same direction as the thrust asymmetry, getting rid of this extra drag by feathering the propeller makes the thrust asymmetry a little easier to counteract, and this is quite noticeable when doing engine failure training on a twin propeller aircraft. Therefore, the answer is that the left yaw is reduced (not removed completely, of course).

content.question: What causes a powerful old wartime piston single-engine aircraft with a anticlockwise rotating propeller to veer to the right when the throttle is increased to maximum power during take-off?

options.B: Gyro effect.
options.C: Asymmetric effect.
options.D: Slipstream effect.

key_points: Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario

TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron)
GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope
learning.explanation: Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. SLIPSTREAM EFFECT The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Note: Asymmetric blade effect and gyroscopic precession come into play at rotation. One could argue that slipstream effect could also be an option. However, according to feedback, “torque effect” was the correct answer.

content.question: You are flying a twin engine aircraft with clockwise rotating propellers, if you get an engine failure what should you do?

options.A: Yaw and roll towards the live engine.
options.B: Roll and yaw to the dead.
options.C: Yaw to the dead, roll live.
options.D: Yaw to the live, roll to the dead.

key_points: Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure

In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine

Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine
learning.explanation: Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure. In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine. Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine. The typical action is to apply rudder in the direction of the live engine to counteract this forward slip. However, while the nose will be aligned with the desired flight path doing this, the actual flight path is a side slip towards the dead engine side, which creates excess drag. The only available counter to this is to bank the airplane into the direction of the live engine to counteract the rudder force using the horizontal component of lift. The angle of bank must not exceed 5°, to prevent excessive loss of vertical lift component.

learning.explanation: If a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure when airborne, there are two immediate aerodynamic effects: The initial effect is the yawing that occurs due to the asymmetry of the thrust line. The second effect is roll. This occurs when the aircraft continues to yaw towards the failed engine resulting in a decrease in lift from the retreating wing and a yaw-induced roll towards the failed engine. In this case, when experiencing a right engine failure, the aircraft will bank towards the right. This roll will be more marked if the flaps are extended, the left wing will create significantly greater lift.

key_points: In the event of an engine failure of a multi-engine airplane the strength of the asymmetric yawing moment caused by its failure is dependent on the distance of the failed engine from the CG, measured at right angles to the longitudinal axis
The further outboard the failed engine is located the greater is the induced yawing moment

Because the engines of a propeller-driven airplane have to be mounted on the wing sufficiently far from the fuselage to account the necessary propeller clearance then these airplanes always experience a large yawing moment when an engine fails that may be difficult to control
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure of a multi-engine airplane the strength of the asymmetric yawing moment caused by its failure is dependent on the distance of the failed engine from the CG, measured at right angles to the longitudinal axis. The further outboard the failed engine is located the greater is the induced yawing moment. Because the engines of a propeller-driven airplane have to be mounted on the wing sufficiently far from the fuselage to account the necessary propeller clearance then these airplanes always experience a large yawing moment when an engine fails that may be difficult to control. This is not so with a jet airplane because the wing-mounted engines on these airplanes can be mounted relatively close to the fuselage thus creating a relatively short moment arm, which produces a small yawing moment that is easier to control. In such a situation the propeller-driven airplane also has a greater tendency to roll than the jet-propelled airplane. On suffering an engine failure, the unbalanced thrust and drag produces a yawing moment that must be counteracted by the deflection of the rudder. The side force generated by the rudder deflection when multiplied by the moment arm (the distance that the center of pressure of the rudder is from the CG) has to produce a counteracting moment equal to and opposite to the yawing moment.

content.question: Regarding propeller efficiency, it's typically defined as the ratio of...

options.B: power input to fuel consumption

key_points: Note: there are a few of these questions being used on the ECQB (EASA Question Bank) and none of them are particularly well worded
This seems like the worst in our opinion, but at least all the other options are significantly incorrect, so it makes it easy enough to answer, even if not truly correct
This could show up differently in the exam anyway, so as long as you know the simple theory behind it, you should have no problem
learning.explanation: Note: there are a few of these questions being used on the ECQB (EASA Question Bank) and none of them are particularly well worded. This seems like the worst in our opinion, but at least all the other options are significantly incorrect, so it makes it easy enough to answer, even if not truly correct. This could show up differently in the exam anyway, so as long as you know the simple theory behind it, you should have no problem. The efficiency of any system is determined by the ratio of the output power to the input power. The force developed by the engine and delivered to the propeller via the shaft is the rotational force of the propeller, the propeller torque. The power delivered from the shaft to the propeller (input power) is the product of the torque and the angular velocity of the propeller shaft (Torque × RPM). The thrust developed by the propeller is the product of the mass of air moved and the acceleration given to it by the propeller. The power developed by the propeller is the product of the thrust and the TAS (Thrust × Axial Speed). Propeller efficiency is the ratio of the propeller output power developed to the engine power delivered (input power). A well-designed propeller is typically 80% efficient when operating at its optimum blade angle of attack. Of course, this question doesn't have that as an option, so the closest option is "Thrust produced to power input". The ratio is therefore not correct, as thrust is not power output, they different by a factor of the true airspeed, but it's the closest they have given us. Why they keep using thrust to describe the output of a propeller, we have no idea, as a whole branch of PoF is to do with the fact we only measure propeller power, not thrust. As for the other options: "power input to fuel consumption" is a measure of the engine efficiency. "airspeed to thrust produced" is not really a useful measure of anything. "torque to rotational speed" is not a useful measure either. When these two are multiplied together, they get the input power, but as a ratio, they are useless to us.

learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. It is usually approximately 85◦ because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist. This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine. For a single-engine airplane feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance because it does not require such a steep glide angle to maintain the required airspeed. As such, feathering the propeller increases the gliding range and endurance. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag reduces the amount of thrust required to counteract the asymmetric force of the propeller of the failed engine and there is sufficient rudder authority remaining to enable the pilot to safely control the airplane.

learning.explanation: The blade angle of a fixed-pitch propeller is constant, but the helix angle and the angle of attack will vary according to its forward speed. To ensure its efficient operation the blade angle of attack of a fixed-pitch propeller must be close to the optimum and is that which produces the greatest excess of horizontal lift (thrust) over drag. learning.explanation: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. In the same way, as the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given rpm and blade angle. Ice separating from the propeller blades, as well as vibration due to propeller imbalance, may cause damage to the airplane structure. Since ice on the propeller blades reduces the available thrust, extra power may be required from the engine to overcome the increased drag, decreasing propeller efficiency. Note: Propeller icing can be expected to reduce propeller efficiency by up to 10% normally, but could up to 20% in very severe icing. Propeller icing occurs on the leading edge, but is least at the tip of the blade, where the high rotational speed tends to shed the ice more easily. For that reason, icing will be reduced by INCREASING propeller rpm, not reducing it. The loss of aircraft performance in icing conditions is mainly due to ice formation on the rest of the wings and airframe, with a smaller contribution coming from the propeller icing.

key_points: Note: The propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM
A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air
The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine
learning.explanation: Note: The propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air. The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine. BLADE ANGLE (PITCH) The angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation. ANGLE OF ATTACK The path of the propeller through the air determines the direction of the relative airflow. The angle between the blade chord and the relative airflow is the angle of attack (α). The angle of attack (α) is the result of propeller rotational velocity (RPM) and aircraft forward velocity (TAS). Because the rotational velocity of the blade increases with distance from the propeller shaft and the fact that the aeroplane is moving forward, then the angle of attack of the blade varies at different distances from the shaft. CONSTANT SPEED PROPELLER The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the aeroplane speed changes. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. FIGURE 1 The diagram shows the conditions during the early stages of the take-off roll. The RPM is set to maximum and the TAS is low. The angle of attack is optimum and maximum available efficiency is obtained. As the aircraft continues to accelerate, the TAS will increase, which decreases the angle of attack of the blades. Less thrust will be generated and less propeller torque. This gives less resistance for the engine to overcome and RPM would tend to increase. The propeller governor senses the RPM increase and increases pitch to maintain the blade angle of attack constant. FIGURE 2 The diagram shows conditions when the engine and propeller have been set for cruise conditions. Optimum throttle and RPM settings are listed in the aircraft Flight Manual. Whatever configuration into which the aircraft is placed, climb, descent or bank, the CSU will adjust the blade angle (propeller pitch) to maintain the RPM which has been set. At least it will try to maintain constant RPM.

content.question: While performing a go-around, an aircraft with a right-hand propeller will initially tend to…

options.A: yaw to the right and roll to the left.
options.B: yaw to the right and roll to the right.
options.C: yaw to the left and roll to the right.
options.D: yaw to the left and roll to the left.

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 814917 but without the story in the question Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect
TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller
In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 814917 but without the story in the question Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect. TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. anti-clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and is particularly noticeable in a go-around scenario, where the airspeed over the ailerons is low, and maximum power is applied, not only causing a large increase in torque effect but also the rotational acceleration of the propeller provides a further effect. So that's why the aircraft will roll to the left in this scenario. But the yaw is, unfortunately, a little more complicated as there are a few extra factors at play, in fact almost all the secondary effects are here. The asymmetric blade effect (P-factor) will cause a yaw to the left; The gyroscopic precession causes a smaller, temporary yaw to the right whilst pitching up; The slipstream effect causes an increased yaw to the left; and Therefore, overall the aircraft yaws to the left, hence the need for more right rudder than you expect if you've trained in an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, which is highly likely. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the left hand side, causing a tail-right, nose-left moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause a forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the left of the propeller disc, which is a transient yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, due to a higher angle of attack, so the thrust line of this clockwise propeller is to the right of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (right of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the left.

learning.explanation: SECONDARY EFFECTS OF THE PROPELLER Due to its rotation a propeller generates yawing, rolling and pitching moments. These are due to several different causes: Torque reaction, Gyroscopic precession, Spiral (asymmetric) slipstream effect and Asymmetric blade effect. Torque reaction. A counter-clockwise rotating propeller produces a clockwise moment that must be counteracted by ailerons. During take-off this will apply a greater down load to the left wheel, causing more rolling resistance on the left wheel making the aircraft want to yaw to the left. Gyroscopic precession. Propeller can also be considered a gyroscope as it is a certain mass, which is rotating. Gyroscopes want to maintain their plane of rotation. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. if an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller is pitched nose-up, imagine that a forward force has been applied to the bottom of the propeller disc. The force will “emerge” at 90° in the direction of rotation, i.e. a right yawing moment. Spiral Slipstream. As the propeller rotates it produces a backward flow of air, or slipstream, which rotates around the aircraft. This spiral slipstream causes a change in airflow around the fin (vertical stabilizer). Due to the direction of propeller rotation (clockwise) the spiral slipstream meets the fin at an angle from the left, producing a sideways force on the fin to the right.

learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine. learning.explanation: A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air. The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine. BLADE ANGLE (PITCH) The angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation. ANGLE OF ATTACK The path of the propeller through the air determines the direction of the relative airflow. The angle between the blade chord and the relative airflow is the angle of attack (α). The angle of attack (α) is the result of propeller rotational velocity (RPM) and aircraft forward velocity (TAS). Because the rotational velocity of the blade increases with distance from the propeller shaft and the fact that the aeroplane is moving forward, then the angle of attack of the blade varies at different distances from the shaft. CONSTANT SPEED PROPELLER The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the aeroplane speed changes. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. Figure shows the conditions during the early stages of the take-off roll. The RPM is set to maximum and the TAS is low. The angle of attack is optimum and maximum available efficiency is obtained. As the aircraft continues to accelerate, the TAS will increase, which decreases the angle of attack of the blades. Less thrust will be generated and less propeller torque. This gives less resistance for the engine to overcome and RPM would tend to increase. The propeller governor senses the RPM increase and increases pitch to maintain the blade angle of attack constant.

content.question: Which of the following situations decribes the most favourable situation in case of an engine failure on a twin engine aeroplane?
