key_points: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped the same as wings

As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: An aircraft rarely flies at 0º Angle of Attack, and is always pitched slightly up from this
This means that the down-going blade will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust
learning.explanation: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped the same as wings. As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: An aircraft rarely flies at 0º Angle of Attack, and is always pitched slightly up from this. This means that the down-going blade will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust. This then means that the down-going blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade. For this reason, the thrust line will be displaced to one side of the propeller disc (the down-going section). Propellers both rotating clockwise (same direction): if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a thrust arm further from the centre of the aircraft. The failure of the left-hand engine will therefore result in a larger yaw effect (as the right hand engine produces power further away from the longitudinal axis). The left engine is therefore the critical engine, as its failure causes a worse power asymmetry. Counter-rotating propellers: Some aircraft are made so the engines rotate the opposite of each other - called counter-rotating. The most effective method is have them both rotate inwards (right engine anticlockwise, left engine clockwise), as the down-going blades are close to the centre of the aircraft, and there is less asymmetry after any engine failure. The question also mentions outwards rotating propellers. These would serve no added purpose, as the asymmetry would be high after either engine failure. Counter rotating propellers have no critical engine, as both failure scenarios produce equal asymmetry. Therefore, the correct option is: Failure of the right engine if both engines are counter rotating inwards, as this guarantees that the thrust vector will be as close to the centre of the aircraft as possible. Note: "The failure of the left engine if both engines are rotating in the same direction" is unknown, because it is correct if the engines are rotating anti-clockwise, but not when the engines are rotating clockwise. As we don't have that information, we can not say it is correct (and also, clockwise rotation is generally more common).

learning.explanation: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust. The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller. The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. Thrust acts parallel to the direction of flight, whilst propeller torque (the resistance to the motion in the plane of rotation) acts perpendicular to the direction of flight. The propeller torque must thus be overcome or balanced by engine torque for a propeller section to provide thrust.

content.question: The twist of a propeller blade from hub to tip is to...

options.A: maintain constant thrust along the blade.
options.B: maintain a constant blade angle.
options.C: maintain a constant angle of attack along the blade.
options.D: maintain constant speed.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.07.01.03.02: Explain why blade twist is necessary. As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time. The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i.e. not forwards speed). The forwards speed of airflow into the propeller is the same for all sections of the blade, but the lateral speed of the propeller varies massively along the length of the blade. This means the angle of the oncoming airflow is very different for the propeller tip as for the root (near the hub). For this reason, the propeller blade is twisted very significantly between the root and the tip, in order to make sure that the angle of attack remains roughly constant along the length of the blade. The root of the propeller has a very large blade angle and the tip has a much smaller blade angle, but - at the optimum RPM and forwards speed (TAS) - the angle of attack of the whole propeller should be close to the optimum angle of attack. As for the other options: The thrust is not meant to be constant at all locations on the propeller, as there is no way to make the slow moving root produce the same amount of thrust as the fast moving tip, and also you don't want the tip to produce too much thrust as it could warp the blade. This one is a common misconception so be sure not to get it wrong. The blade angle is changed by twisting the blade, an un-twisted propeller would have constant blade angle (and very poor performance/efficiency). All sections of the propeller cannot all go at the same speed as this is physically impossible.

learning.explanation: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiraling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis.

learning.explanation: Blade pitch refers to the process of turning the propeller blades’ angle of attack into or out of the wind, depending on the best performance at that point. Propeller pitch is often referred to as ‘coarse’ for a greater horizontal blade angle and ‘fine’ for a more vertical angle. The thrust from a propeller depends on its speed and angle of attack. As the tip of the propeller has a higher speed than the hub, propellers ate often twisted along the blade to remain uniform thrust along the blade. A propeller that is catching a lot of air and therefore generating a lot of drag is called a windmilling propeller. We can use a technique called feathering to adjust the angle of attack of the propeller so that it meets the least amount of air, thus generating less drag.

key_points: A propeller blade is just a wing
Anything that happens to a propeller blade can be translated into our knowledge of how a wing behaves

The main difference is that the air interacting with a propeller blade is partially from ahead of the aircraft, brought in by the TAS (True Airspeed) of the aircraft, and the other component of the incoming air is from the rotational speed of the propeller
learning.explanation: A propeller blade is just a wing. Anything that happens to a propeller blade can be translated into our knowledge of how a wing behaves. The main difference is that the air interacting with a propeller blade is partially from ahead of the aircraft, brought in by the TAS (True Airspeed) of the aircraft, and the other component of the incoming air is from the rotational speed of the propeller. This means that the angle of relative airflow will change, depending on the RPM and TAS, and their relationship. In the case of this diagram, we have one force being created by the propeller blade, split into two components. Number 1 component is opposing the rotation of the propeller, where number 2 component is in the direction of flight. This makes number 2 quite simple, it is the thrust produced. It is quite a similar force vector to the lift created by a fixed wing. Number 1 is the opposing force of the propeller rotation, and therefore the opposing force to the engine. This means that it is the opposing torque, known sometimes just as "torque" or "torque drag". Torque is the measure of how much force an engine can apply in one rotation, and for an engine at constant RPM, the torque from the engine will match the "torque drag" of the propeller. Notice how, for a wing, number 1 would be closely related to the drag of the wing, hence even easier to remember "torque drag"

key_points: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes

This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds
Originally there were only two pitch settings, fine for take-off and climb and coarse for cruise and high-speed flight
learning.explanation: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes. This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds. Originally there were only two pitch settings, fine for take-off and climb and coarse for cruise and high-speed flight. Subsequently, the fully variable pitch constant-speed propeller was introduced so that the optimum blade angle of attack could be maintained over the whole range of operating speeds for that airplane. This facility not only improves the propeller efficiency but also decreases the fuel consumption. The pitch angle or blade angle of a constant-speed propeller (fixe RPM) increases (or coarsens) with increasing TAS. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. Propeller efficiency improves with increased TAS; however, it is limited to that blade angle beyond which the propeller will no longer produce any thrust.

learning.explanation: The blade angle of a fixed-pitch propeller is constant, but the helix angle and the angle of attack will vary according to its forward speed. To ensure its efficient operation the blade angle of attack of a fixed-pitch propeller must be close to the optimum and is that which produces the greatest excess of horizontal lift (thrust) over drag. A large blade angle or coarse pitch is suitable for high-speed flight (cruise). The geometric pitch is the distance the propeller would travel forward in one complete revolution if it were moving through the air at the blade angle. The higher the blade angle the higher the geometric pitch. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. In low forward speed flight, the angle of attack for is large. This produces a large amount of thrust but at the same time it creates a large amount of drag. To maintain a constant RPM, it is essential to overcome the drag and that requires a high propeller torque. The propeller efficiency in these circumstances is low. By increasing the speed, the helix angle increases. Although the angle of attack of is smaller and less thrust is produced the amount of drag induced is significantly less, this makes the propeller efficiency proportionately greater. It is this speed that attains the greatest propeller efficiency. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

key_points: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down
The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop

Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

key_points: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust
The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller
The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade
learning.explanation: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust. The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller. The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. Thrust acts parallel to the direction of flight, whilst propeller torque (the resistance to the motion in the plane of rotation) acts perpendicular to the direction of flight. The propeller torque must thus be overcome or balanced by engine torque for a propeller section to provide thrust. Engine torque will rotate the propeller and the propeller, while creating thrust (propeller lift) will resist the engine torque with propeller torque (propeller drag). If the engine and propeller torque are in balance, the engine RPM is constant (Newton’s first law of motion)

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect TORQUE REACTION This occurs because the air resists the motion of the propeller

learning.explanation: At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs, approaches to power-on stalls or go-around), the aircraft will have the tendecy to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect TORQUE REACTION This occurs because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. counter- clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and, whilst on the ground, places more weight on the left wheel than the right wheel. This effectively increases the rolling resistance (i.e. drag) of the left wheel, thus slowing the aircraft down and causing it to yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc.

key_points: For a given RPM, the rotational velocity is much higher at the tip of the blade than at the root
This results in the relative airflow approaching the blade at significantly different angles along its length
If unaddressed, the blade root, with its low rotational speed, would experience a very low angle of attack, while the blade tip, with its high rotational speed, would have a very high angle of attack
learning.explanation: For a given RPM, the rotational velocity is much higher at the tip of the blade than at the root. This results in the relative airflow approaching the blade at significantly different angles along its length. If unaddressed, the blade root, with its low rotational speed, would experience a very low angle of attack, while the blade tip, with its high rotational speed, would have a very high angle of attack. To solve this problem and distribute thrust evenly across the propeller, a substantial amount of twist is applied to the blade (much more than the washout twist given to a wing). This blade twist reduces the blade angle from the hub to the tip, maintaining a constant angle of attack. This twist is applied to all blades, whether they have fixed or variable pitch.

key_points: When the propeller is rotating, aerodynamic losses occur near the hub and at the blade tips
Near the hub, the airflow is disrupted where the propeller blade sections are thicker and near the engine
Vortices form at the propeller blade tips in a similar manner as at the wing tips
learning.explanation: When the propeller is rotating, aerodynamic losses occur near the hub and at the blade tips. Near the hub, the airflow is disrupted where the propeller blade sections are thicker and near the engine. Vortices form at the propeller blade tips in a similar manner as at the wing tips. This results in induced drag and a reduction in the actual amount of thrust developed in this region. In practice, only a small part of the propeller blade is effective in producing thrust at normal operating angles of attack. This is generally between 60% and 90% of the distance from the blade hub to the tip. At positive angles of attack, the greatest useful thrust is produced at 75% of the tip radius. By convention, the blade angle at this radius is the reference pitch for the whole propeller blade.

Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. 1. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). Statement 1 is correct. 2. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect. 3. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. Statement 3 is correct. 4. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Statement 4 is correct.

learning.explanation: Gyroscopic precession manifests as a reaction when force is exerted on a gyroscope. In the context of a rotating propeller, this reaction occurs 90° in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. For instance, in an aircraft equipped with a clockwise rotating propeller, pitching the nose up applies a forward force to the bottom of the propeller disc. key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession
The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. The Gyroscopic Effect is more significant in situations of high power (RPM) and low forward speed, such as take-off or low speed climbs. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up.

key_points: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down
The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop

Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

content.question:
Considering the operation of a clockwise rotating propeller, complete the following sentences about propeller torque.
When the propeller is windmilling, propeller torque acts (1) _____. During negative pitch (reverse thrust) operation, propeller torque acts (2) _____.

options.A: (1) clockwise; (2) clockwise
options.B: (1) anti-clockwise; (2) anti-clockwise
options.C: (1) clockwise; (2) anti-clockwise
options.D: (1) anti-clockwise; (2) clockwise

key_points: The two aerodynamic forces acting on a propeller are similar to that of a wing, which has lift (what we want) and drag (what we don't want)
For a propeller though, these forces become Thrust (what we want) and Torque (what we don't want)
This torque is specifically propeller torque, which pushes back against the rotation of the engine, and thereby opposes engine torque
learning.explanation: The two aerodynamic forces acting on a propeller are similar to that of a wing, which has lift (what we want) and drag (what we don't want). For a propeller though, these forces become Thrust (what we want) and Torque (what we don't want). This torque is specifically propeller torque, which pushes back against the rotation of the engine, and thereby opposes engine torque. In normal operations, as in the first image above, the propeller torque is acting against the direction of rotation, so in this case, anti-clockwise. However, if the engine is windmilling, (second image) then there is no engine torque to rotate the propeller (usually because it has failed), however, the windmill effect means that the incoming airflow actually pushes the propeller the correct way round, which is clockwise in this case, and also produces a lot of negative thrust (drag). The aerodynamic propeller torque is therefore with the direction of rotation (clockwise), as it is the driving force, and strangely the engine drag is the opposing force (anti-clockwise) in this case. Therefore, the windmilling propeller torque direction is clockwise. Reverse thrust (negative pitch) operations are a whole other scenario (third image above). Often called the "beta range", this is where the propeller pitch is sent past the fine pitch stop and the angle of attack becomes very negative. The engine is still running the propeller at this point, often at high RPMs, as this negative angle of attack produces a lot of reverse thrust. The driving torque is still provided by the engine in this case though, and the propeller (aerodynamic) torque is opposing the direction of rotation, so even though the thrust produced is negative, the torques are still the same as normal operation. In this case, the propeller torque is anti-clockwise. Remember that a propeller is designed never to turn the wrong direction. If it is a clockwise rotating propeller, it will always want to turn clockwise. No scenario other than hand pulling will make it turn anticlockwise.

content.question: When on final approach to an airport in a single engine piston aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, the pilot anticipates that they may have to go around due to traffic still occupying the runway, so is thinking in advance how the aircraft will react. key_points: Note: This is similar to question 812009 but seen with more of a story in the question
Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect
TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 812009 but seen with more of a story in the question. Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect. TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. anti-clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and is particularly noticeable in a go-around scenario, where the airspeed over the ailerons is low, and maximum power is applied, not only causing a large increase in torque effect but also the rotational acceleration of the propeller provides a further effect. So that's why the aircraft will roll to the left in this scenario. But the yaw is, unfortunately, a little more complicated as there are a few extra factors at play, in fact almost all the secondary effects are here. The asymmetric blade effect (P-factor) will cause a yaw to the left; The gyroscopic precession causes a smaller, temporary yaw to the right whilst pitching up; The slipstream effect causes an increased yaw to the left; and Therefore, overall the aircraft yaws to the left, hence the need for more right rudder than you expect if you've trained in an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, which is highly likely. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the left hand side, causing a tail-right, nose-left moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause a forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the left of the propeller disc, which is a transient yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, due to a higher angle of attack, so the thrust line of this clockwise propeller is to the right of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (right of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the left.

key_points: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller
It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist

This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine
learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist. This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine. For a single-engine airplane feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance because it does not require such a steep glide angle to maintain the required airspeed. As such, feathering the propeller increases the gliding range and endurance. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag reduces the amount of thrust required to counteract the asymmetric force of the propeller of the failed engine and there is sufficient rudder authority remaining to enable the pilot to safely control the airplane.

learning.explanation: The critical engine of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effects on the aircraft's handling and performance. When one of the engines on a typical multi-engine aircraft becomes inoperative, a thrust asymmetry exists. The thrust asymmetry can be different, depending on how the engine is mounted. Particularly on a propeller aircraft, the propellers are subject to the asymmetric blade effect, called P-factor. This occurs because the propeller does not spin perpendicular to the airflow, as the aircraft is flying with an angle of attack. This means that the down-going blades on the propeller have a higher angle of attack and longer track, so they produce more thrust. Therefore, the thrust vector of the engine is located not centrally, but more towards the down-going blade side. This means that one engine has its thrust vector further from the aircraft's longitudinal axis, and therefore if the other engine fails, it has a worse effect on yaw. This engine (with the worst effect on yaw) is called the critical engine. As the propellers on the pilot's new aircraft rotate anticlockwise (when viewed from behind), the down-going blades are on the left hand side, so the thrust lines of the engines are to the left of the engine. Therefore, losing the right hand engine would leave the pilot with the remaining thrust line furthest from the cockpit. The right hand engine is therefore the critical engine. Note that the figure shown above is the opposite, it is for an aircraft with clockwise rotating engines, as most do.

learning.explanation: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust. The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller. The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

content.question: Consider an aeroplane with two wing-mounted counter-rotating propellers. The torque reaction from the propeller on the left wing will be in the (1) _____ direction to the torque reaction generated on the right wing, resulting in a/an (2) _____ of the overall torque reaction.

options.B: (1) opposite; (2) increase.
options.C: (1) same; (2) decrease.
options.D: (1) same; (2) increase.

key_points: Short explanation: Counter-rotating propellers are employed not only to minimize the impact of p-factor but also as a secondary measure to diminish torque effects
The reduction in torque occurs through the configuration, for instance, when the propellers rotate inwards, with the left engine turning clockwise and the right engine turning anti-clockwise
In this setup, the torque effect generated by each engine is in the opposite direction, theoretically equal in magnitude
learning.explanation: Short explanation: Counter-rotating propellers are employed not only to minimize the impact of p-factor but also as a secondary measure to diminish torque effects. The reduction in torque occurs through the configuration, for instance, when the propellers rotate inwards, with the left engine turning clockwise and the right engine turning anti-clockwise. In this setup, the torque effect generated by each engine is in the opposite direction, theoretically equal in magnitude. Consequently, the theoretical result is a reduction of the torque effect to zero. Further information: Most traditional twin-engine aircraft have clockwise-rotating propellers when viewed from behind. When equipped with co-rotating propellers (both rotating clockwise) on a small twin, there is minimal torque reaction around the airplane's center of gravity until one engine fails. A left turning tendency would then occur. In contrast, small twins with counter-rotating propellers can reduce torque reaction after an engine failure. In this configuration, the propeller on the left-hand engine (Engine nr.1) rotates clockwise, while the one on the right-hand engine (Engine nr.2) rotates counter-clockwise. The primary advantage lies in balancing torque and P-factor effects, ensuring there is no critical engine in the event of failure. The critical engine, in the context of a multi-engine airplane, refers to the engine whose failure would result in the most adverse impact on performance and handling abilities.

content.question: An aircraft is performing an approach with one engine inoperative. The outside air temperature at sea level is minus 10 degrees. The aircraft is unstable on final and the pilot decides to perform a missed approach. What is the effect on VMCA?

options.B: High engine performance due to higher air density, therefore VMCA increases.

options.D: More rudder control effectiveness due to higher air density, so VMCA decreases.

key_points: Minimum Control Speed - VMCA When an engine fails or is inoperative in-flight, the rudder is used to counteract the asymmetrical thrust yawing moment
Roll effects are counteracted by the ailerons
The counteracting forces generated by the aerodynamic control surfaces are proportional to the square of the airspeed (V2), to the area of the control surfaces (S) and to the air density
learning.explanation: Minimum Control Speed - VMCA When an engine fails or is inoperative in-flight, the rudder is used to counteract the asymmetrical thrust yawing moment. Roll effects are counteracted by the ailerons. The counteracting forces generated by the aerodynamic control surfaces are proportional to the square of the airspeed (V2), to the area of the control surfaces (S) and to the air density. For a given size of the vertical tail with rudder, there is a speed below which the generated rudder side force is not large enough to counteract the asymmetrical thrust, or below which the ailerons are not effective anymore: the heading and/or bank angle cannot be maintained below this speed. This speed is called Minimum Control speed in the Air VMCA. With regards to this question, Cold air is more dense. Engines are able to produce more power in colder weather due to being able to achieve higher mass flow with the higher density air. As power increases, the operative engine requires more rudder authority to maintain directional stability due to the increase in thrust. As a result, the airplane requires higher indicated airspeeds to maintain directional stability. Therefore, VMCA increases.

content.question: Upon first contact with their destination aerodrome, the crew of a jet aeroplane is informed to expect a few holds due to high traffic. What can the crew do to increase their aircraft's maximum endurance?

options.B: Climb to the optimum altitude in order to increase specific range.
options.C: Cruise with VMD in order to minimise fuel used per unit of time.
options.D: Request a continuous descent in order to reduce the thrust setting.

key_points: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern
In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed
As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on
learning.explanation: The pilot of an aircraft in this scenario knows that they are going to have to wait some time before landing, which usually means entering a holding pattern. In order to maximise the amount of fuel they have left at this point, the crew should slow down and fly the rest of the way at the best endurance speed. As they are only going to end up holding anyway, they might as well save some fuel in the cruise, and have to do less holding patterns later on. This is assuming that they have already "joined the queue" at their destination airport, which is implied in the question. The best endurance speed in a jet aircraft is the speed at which the engines need to produce the least thrust, as thrust is directly proportional to fuel flow, and we want to make our fuel flow the lowest it can be. The speed of minimum thrust required is the speed of least drag (as thrust directly opposed drag). We called this VMD, for minimum drag speed, and it is the speed that aircraft fly in the holding pattern, and when it is time in the air that is most desirable, rather than distance gone. It occurs at the bottom of the "total drag" curve as shown in the annex above, where the combination of induced and parasite drag equals the lowest value. There is no point climbing up to the optimum altitude at this stage, as it is not an efficient use of fuel to climb just before descent. Also, that option is not correct because we do not care about maximum range now, only maximum endurance.

key_points: If an engine fails during the take-off of a multi-engine aircraft a significant yawing moment will be experienced due to asymmetric thrust
In order to maintain directional control and keeping the aircraft in equilibrium around the yaw axis, the pilot must apply corrective action
Above a certain speed this will be possible using aerodynamic controls only
learning.explanation: If an engine fails during the take-off of a multi-engine aircraft a significant yawing moment will be experienced due to asymmetric thrust. In order to maintain directional control and keeping the aircraft in equilibrium around the yaw axis, the pilot must apply corrective action. Above a certain speed this will be possible using aerodynamic controls only. If the aircraft is still on the ground this means the use of the rudder, if the aircraft is airborne, the pilot can also apply bank by using the ailerons. The greater the thrust of this operating engine(s), the greater the yawing moment will be and the greater the aerodynamic forces to counteract this yawing moment would be required. VMCA = Minimum control speed in the take-off configuration with gear up – the minimum calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control and maintain straight flight using no more than 5° of bank without required exceptional piloting skill or the aeroplane adopting a dangerous attitude or changing heading by more than 20°. An increased bank angle beyond 5°, while keeping the rudder centered, may lead to a fin stall, due to an extreme sideslip angle, but when decreasing the bank angle below 5° to 0°, rudder deflection has to be increased and therefore VMCA will increase, too. Equilibrium of moments about the normal axis (also called yaw or vertical axis) is provided by rudder deflection (yaw) Equilibrium of moments about the lateral axis is provided by elevator deflection (pitch) Equilibrium of moments about the longitudinal axis is provided by aileron deflection (roll) Note: Forces along the lateral axis is not the same like moments around the lateral axis. Forces along the lateral axis act around the longitudinal axis. Therefore an equilibrium along the lateral axis always requires bank or sideslip.

content.question: A twin-engine propeller aircraft suffers a left engine failure during the approach. The pilot applies full thrust on the other engine to go around. What effect do the flaps have on the aircraft in this scenario?

options.A: Flaps increase drag and increase the roll to the left.
options.B: Flaps reduce drag and increase the roll to the right.
options.C: Flaps reduce lift and increase the roll to the left.
options.D: Flaps increase lift and decrease the roll to the right.

key_points: Note: This question has appeared in the past in different forms such as question 812045
The inclusion of "propeller aircraft" in the question is unclear, some feedback indicates this may be present, some does not
The question appears to be much easier to answer with it present, though the same answer remains correct even if it is not (though the effect is less pronounced on jet aircraft)
learning.explanation: Note: This question has appeared in the past in different forms such as question 812045. The inclusion of "propeller aircraft" in the question is unclear, some feedback indicates this may be present, some does not. The question appears to be much easier to answer with it present, though the same answer remains correct even if it is not (though the effect is less pronounced on jet aircraft). If a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure when airborne, there are two immediate aerodynamic effects: The initial effect is the yawing that occurs due to the asymmetry of the thrust line. The second effect is roll. This occurs when the aircraft continues to yaw towards the failed engine resulting in a decrease in lift from the retreating wing and a yaw-induced roll towards the failed engine. In this case, when experiencing a left engine failure, the aircraft will bank towards the left. This roll will be more marked if the flaps are extended, as the right wing will create significantly greater lift. This occurs simply due to the secondary effect of the yawing moment anyway, but the effect of flaps on an engine-failure-induced roll is worse for a propeller aircraft as the slipstream induced lift is a greater proportion of the total lift when flaps are extended, so losing this is a greater roll moment when flaps are extended than when the wing is clean. The flaps also increase drag quite significantly, and this can make it difficult or impossible for some less powerful twin-prop aircraft to climb single engine in the event of a go-around. Often it is best for them to accelerate and retract flaps first, then begin a climb with a clean configuration.

There is a minimum IAS (VMC), below which it is impossible for the pilot to maintain directional control with asymmetric thrust. VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the takeoff run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill. Airworthiness Authorities, in this case the EASA, have laid down conditions which must be satisfied when establishing the minimum airspeeds for inclusion in the Flight Manual of a new aircraft type. content.question:
An aircraft with a mass of 60 tons is performing a co-ordinated level turn with 30 degrees of bank. In these conditions what is the magnitude of the Centripetal Force?
Assume g = 10 m/s2

key_points: Refer to figure During a steady, co-ordinated turn, at a constant altitude, a force must continually act toward the centre of the turn (centripetal force)
If it is not present, the aircraft will be unable to maintain a curved path, but instead will fly off at a tangent
When the aircraft banks, the total lift force tilts; the horizontal component of lift provides the centripetal force and the vertical component of lift supports the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: Refer to figure During a steady, co-ordinated turn, at a constant altitude, a force must continually act toward the centre of the turn (centripetal force). If it is not present, the aircraft will be unable to maintain a curved path, but instead will fly off at a tangent. When the aircraft banks, the total lift force tilts; the horizontal component of lift provides the centripetal force and the vertical component of lift supports the weight of the aircraft. The centripetal force acting on an aircraft gives it acceleration toward the centre of the turn (radial acceleration). In a steady, co-ordinated turn, an aircraft of weight (W - Newtons), travelling at a velocity (TAS) of (V - metres per second) around the circumference of a circle of radius (r - metres), has an acceleration toward the centre of the circle of (V2/r - metres per second per second), so that: FC = (mass x V2) / r = (W / g) x (V2 / r) Where: W = Aircraft Weight (kg) g = Acceleration due to Gravity (10 m/s2) The resulting horizontal and vertical forces that exist during a steady, level turn are: L x sin(ø)= (W / g) x (V2 / r) and L x cos (ø) = W So that Tan (ø) = V2 / (g x r), where ø = angle of bank Replacing the above in the Centripetal Force formula: FC = W x tan ø In this exercise: W = mass x g = 60 000 x 10 = 600 000 N and bank angle (ø) = 30º FC = 600 000 x tan 30º = 346 410 N

learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. RUDDER MOMENT The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force). Note: In this exercise, the left engine failed, which means that initially the yawing moment would be to the left, causing the nose to point to the left. If after the nose is to the right, it means that the pilot might have made a too big rudder input and the nose is now to the right, creating a sideslip. This is why it is important to know what factors influence the rudder moment, one of which is that an increase in rudder input increases its angle of attack, which increases the overall force that the rudder produces.

key_points: Note: We had to modify some of the values in the question to provide a possible answer, so the question may look different in the exam

Please let us know if you see this question in the exam and whatever you can remember from it, thank you! For an aircraft to continue in the same direction at the same speed, the forces on it must be balanced

learning.explanation: Note: We had to modify some of the values in the question to provide a possible answer, so the question may look different in the exam. Please let us know if you see this question in the exam and whatever you can remember from it, thank you! For an aircraft to continue in the same direction at the same speed, the forces on it must be balanced. In straight and level flight, thrust equals drag and lift equals weight, as 2 opposing pairs. When the thrust is lower than the drag, as in this case, the aircraft will start to decelerate. However, in order to remain at the same speed, the pilot can allow a descent to begin. As the aircraft descends, a component of the weight force which alwas points directly down is now pointing in the same direction as the thrust force, and is acting as "thrust" to push the aircraft forwards. The amount of "thrust" provided by the aircraft's weight plus any thrust from the engines should equal the drag on the aircraft in the descent, and the aircraft will maintain a constant speed, and lose altitude. This is shown by the following equation D = T + W sinγ Where D, T and W are Drag, Thrust and Weight. γ = descent angle This can be re-arranged for us to work out the descent angle, γ. The units are all the same and therefore cancel each other out, though feel free to expand out the units in your calculation (125 kN = 125 000 N, etc.): sin γ = (D - T) / W sin γ = (130 - 50) / 1500 sin γ = 0.05333. γ = sin-1 0.05333. γ = 3.06° Therefore the angle of descent is closest to 3°.

content.question: A pallet of freight is added to an aircraft's forward hold mistakenly, instead of the rear hold. What effect will this have on the aircraft's handling characteristics?

options.A: It will make the aircraft more prone to a tailplane stall.
options.B: It will have an effect on the yaw of the aircraft.
options.C: It will make the aircraft more tail heavy, improving its climb gradient.
options.D: It will make the aircraft nose heavy, adversely affecting climb performance.

key_points: Note: This is more of a question that you would expect in performance, but it has been seen in PoF recently

The pallet of freight being placed in the forward hold, instead of where it was supposed to be placed (the aft hold) means that the aircraft's CG is actually further forward than the pilots are aware of
The location of an aircraft's CG is an important factor for many things, both for stability and control as well as for the aircraft's performance
learning.explanation: Note: This is more of a question that you would expect in performance, but it has been seen in PoF recently. The pallet of freight being placed in the forward hold, instead of where it was supposed to be placed (the aft hold) means that the aircraft's CG is actually further forward than the pilots are aware of. The location of an aircraft's CG is an important factor for many things, both for stability and control as well as for the aircraft's performance. When the CG of an aircraft is further forward, the aircraft will be more nose heavy, and to counteract this, the tailplane provides a downforce on the tail in order to keep the nose of the aircraft up. This downforce directly opposes what the main wing is doing, producing lift. Therefore, the greater the downforce, the greater the lift that the main wing needs to produce. For every bit of lift the wing produces though, there is some induced drag that occurs, which means that further forward CG locations cause higher drag, and therefore lower climb performance, shorter aircraft range, and generally worse efficiency. It is possible that the forward CG would have an effect on yaw, due to the slightly longer moment arm of the fin and rudder, but the effect would be incredibly small, particularly when compared to the other effects it causes.

learning.explanation: VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the takeoff run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill. The rudder control forces may not exceed 150 pounds (68.1 kg) and, until the airplane becomes airborne, the lateral control may only be used to the extent of keeping the wings level. In the determination of VMCG, assuming that the path of the airplane accelerating with all engines operating is along the center of the runway, its path from the point at which the critical engine is made inoperative to the point at which recovery to a direction parallel to the center line is completed may not deviate more than 30 ft (9.144 m) laterally from the center line at any point. As with VMCA, this must be established with: maximum available take-off power or thrust on the engines. the airplane trimmed for take-off. the most unfavorable CG position. maximum sea level take-off weight. Because the aircraft rotates around the CG, the position of the CG directly affects the length of the rudder arm and, thus, the power of the rudder and fin to maintain directional stability and control. The ‘worst case’ is with the CG at the aft limit. If the requirements can be met in this configuration, the ability to maintain directional control will be enhanced at any other CG location. A more forward CG decreases VMCG.

learning.explanation: Basically speaking, Asymmetric yaw is a result of the moment generated by the drag of the dead engine and the moment generated by the thrust of the live engine. The CG moves along the longitudinal axis which will not alter its distance to both engines => the Asymmetric moment is independent of the CG. However, the damping moment created by the vertical stabilizer depends on the CG position. If the CG moves forward, the damping moment increases. Consequently, Asymmetric yaw decreases. If the airplane has an aft CG at the time of engine failure, the effective moment arm of the rudder is reduced, since all yawing movements take place about the CG. The greater the permissible limits in the travel of the CG, the larger the difference between the effect of engine failure at the two CG limits.

content.question: Approximately how long does it take to fly a complete circle during a horizontal steady co-ordinated turn with a bank angle of 15° and a TAS of 530 kt?

key_points: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated

A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn
If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn
learning.explanation: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated. A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn. If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn. The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. Either condition will be indicated on the turn and slip indicator. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. To maintain altitude and airspeed when executing a turn both the angle of attack and the thrust have to be increased above their level flight values. In a turn, turn radius and rate of turn are defined as: Turn radius=TAS 2/g tan Φ Rate of Turn=g tan Φ/TAS Therefore, turn radius is directly proportional to TAS squared and inversely proportional to bank angle and Rate of Turn is directly proportional to bank angle and inversely proportional to TAS. In this exercise, TAS is equal to 530 knots and the bank angle is 15°: First, convert 530kt to m/s: 530kt x 0.5144 = 272.63m/s Then, calculate the turn radius Turn radius = 272.63 2/10 ∗ tan 15 Turn radius ≈ 27739.66m The circumference is given by: c = 2 x π x r c = 2 x π x 27739.66 c = 174293.45m At 272.63 m/s, it would take approximately 640 seconds to complete the circumference.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Consider the four glide flight paths represented in the annex. If the aeroplane is flying path 2 and the pilot extends the flaps, what would be the new flight path (the corresponding endurance times are shown on the annex)?

options.A: Path 2
options.B: Path 1
options.C: Path 3
options.D: Path 4

key_points: A descent may be with or without power
A descent without power is a glide descent and has no thrust vector
The remaining force vectors, lift, mass and drag
learning.explanation: A descent may be with or without power. A descent without power is a glide descent and has no thrust vector. The remaining force vectors, lift, mass and drag. There are three variables in a glide descent, the IAS, the configuration and the glide angle that can be manipulated to achieve either of two goals, maximum range or maximum endurance. Glide for maximum range The use of flap is restricted to the period of the descent when the IAS has fallen below the maximum speed for lowering flap (VLO). It is, therefore, limited to the final approach path. Using flap increases parasite drag, decreases the Lift/Drag ratio, increases the effective angle of attack and decreases the maximum glide range. Increased flap decreases range because of the increased pitch angle Glide for maximum endurance The speed used during the descent is the rate of movement of the aeroplane along the descent path and is divided into two components: horizontal and vertical. The horizontal component is the aeroplane’s forward movement across the ground, its groundspeed, and the vertical component is its rate of descent. It is essential to reduce the vertical component to a minimum to produce the maximum endurance. The power required is the product of the TAS and the drag. Therefore, the lowest rate of descent is attained at the speed for which the least power is required. Increased flap decreases endurance because of the increased drag. To complete this exercise we are looking for the descent path which displays both a decrease in range and endurance. That is path number 4.

content.question: An aeroplane performs a right turn, the slip indicator is right of neutral. One way to co-ordinate the turn is to apply:

options.A: less right rudder.
options.B: more right bank.
options.C: less right bank.
options.D: more left rudder.

key_points: A coordinated turn is a turn where there is no sideslip or skid, this is the most effective and therefore preferable way to turn
In a coordinated turn, the turn and bank indicator in the plane shows the ball in the center
If the turn is not coordinated, you’re either in a slip or a skid
learning.explanation: A coordinated turn is a turn where there is no sideslip or skid, this is the most effective and therefore preferable way to turn. In a coordinated turn, the turn and bank indicator in the plane shows the ball in the center. If the turn is not coordinated, you’re either in a slip or a skid. These two things are different and shall therefore be eliminated differently. A slipping turn is a turn where the aircraft’s nose is outside of the turning radius and the tail is in the turn radius. A slip is caused by using too much bank and too little rudder. A skidding turn is a turn where the aircraft’s nose is inside of the turning radius and the tail is outside of the turn radius. A skid is caused by using too much rudder and not enough bank.

content.question: When an aeroplane performs a straight steady climb with a 20% climb gradient, the load factor is equal to:

key_points: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal
γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle
The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity
learning.explanation: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal. γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle. The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity. Weight is resolved into two components: one opposite Lift (W cos γ) and the other acting in the same direction as Drag (W sin γ), backwards along the flight path. The requirements for equilibrium are: Thrust must equal the sum of Drag plus the backwards component of Weight; and Lift must equal its opposing component of Weight. For equilibrium at a greater angle of climb, the Lift required will be less, and the backwards component of Weight will be greater. L = W cos γ T = D + W sin γ In a straight steady climb, Lift is less than Weight because Lift only has to support a proportion of the weight, this proportion decreasing as the climb angle increases. The remaining proportion of Weight is supported by engine Thrust. It can be seen that for a straight steady climb the Thrust required is greater than Drag. This is to balance the backward component of Weight acting along the flight path. The climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T−D)/W For very shallow flight path angles (γ), we can assume that lift is approximately equal to Weight, therefore the climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T/W)−(D/L) From the exercise, the climb gradient is 20%: sin γ = 0.2 We can find the climb angle by applying: γ= sin-1 0.2 ≈11.54° Knowing that: L = Wcos γ ⇒ L/W = cos γ = n The load factor is: n = cos11.54° ≈ 0.98

content.question:
Which of these statements about the limiting value of 5 degrees bank angle during VMCA determination are correct or incorrect?
I. As the bank angle is decreased from 5 degrees to 0 degrees, the value of VMCA increases.
II. At any bank angle beyond 5 degrees, VMCA will decrease correspondingly.

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is correct.

key_points: VMCA is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane with that engine still inoperative and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°
With regards to this question, I
As the bank angle is decreased from 5 degrees to 0 degrees, the value of VMCA increases
learning.explanation: VMCA is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane with that engine still inoperative and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°. With regards to this question, I. As the bank angle is decreased from 5 degrees to 0 degrees, the value of VMCA increases. CORRECT When an engine failure occurs during level flight, in order to maintain wings level, a lot of rudder input is necessary. An increase in bank (usually around 2-5º bank angle), reduces the required rudder input, which provides more controllability, decreasing VMCA. But when decreasing the bank angle below 5º (to 0º), rudder deflection has to be increased and, therefore, VMCA will also increase. II. At any bank angle beyond 5 degrees, VMCA will decrease correspondingly. INCORRECT Banking towards the live engine reduces the rudder deflection required and so allows a lower VMCA. 5° maximum is stipulated because larger bank angles would significantly reduce the vertical component of lift; the angle of attack would have to be increased with the added penalty of higher induced drag.

options.A: VS decreases by 77 kt.

n = 1/cos(60º) = 2 g The Stall Speed in the turn (VSNEW) is calculated by: VSNEW = √n x VSOLD VSOLD = 154 kt VSNEW = √2 x 154 = 218 kt To know by how much VS has changed, we should find the difference between VSNEW and VSOLD: VSNEW - VSOLD = 218 - 154 = 64 kt On a turn with 60º, the Stall Speed increases by 64 kt

content.question: In a glide descent, how does the extension of flaps affect the glide distance and time?

options.A: Glide distance decreases and glide time decreases.
options.B: Glide distance increases and glide time decreases.
options.C: Glide distance remains the same and glide time increases.
options.D: Glide distance increases and glide time remains the same.

key_points: Flaps are very useful on aircraft for decreasing the stall speed, allowing aircraft to safely land and take-off at much lower speeds than they would with a clean wing
This has numerous benefits, including the shortening of runways
Flaps have very limited uses in flight, though, and there is a good reason why pilots are so hasty to get rid of them after take-off
learning.explanation: Flaps are very useful on aircraft for decreasing the stall speed, allowing aircraft to safely land and take-off at much lower speeds than they would with a clean wing. This has numerous benefits, including the shortening of runways. Flaps have very limited uses in flight, though, and there is a good reason why pilots are so hasty to get rid of them after take-off. Flaps increase the drag of a wing, reducing climb rates and increasing fuel burn. The use of flaps in a glide descent increases the drag for no real increase in lift (flaps can increase lift, but the aircraft has not got any heavier, so does not need it), and therefore drastically reduce the L/D ratio (Lift to Drag ratio). The L/D ratio is what decides the glide angle, and is highest in a clean configuration. Flaps cause a steeper glide angle, decreasing the possible glide distance. This extra drag also leads to a greater rate of descent, meaning that the aircraft will have less glide endurance, and the glide time is therefore decreased. If the question mentioned that the pilot slowed down due to extending flaps, then it is possible that the glide time could remain the same or increase, as the lower airspeed means that, even at a steeper glide angle, the aircraft might have a similar or possibly lower rate of descent. As no mention was made of this in the question, and none of the options allow it anyway, we will discount it, but please be aware that it could be asked in such a way, and that may be the correct answer. No matter what the question though.

content.question: Whilst climbing in a jet aircraft, all the pitot tubes become frozen over. The IAS is gradually increasing and eventually reaches the maximum operating airspeed. Which of the following is correct?

options.A: If the pilots do not recognise the unreliable airspeed condition, reducing thrust to control the IAS may cause the aircraft to stall.
options.B: The air data computers should notice this fault and apply a suitable correction to get the correct IAS indication.
options.C: The auto-throttle system will prevent you from exceeding limitations.
options.D: If the autopilot is engaged, it will detect the malfunction and fly the actual airspeed, no matter the pitot blockages.

key_points: This is quite close to being an instrumentation question, but has been seen in PoF exams recently

If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (acts like an altimeter)
They tell us this in the question, perhaps because we are not expected to know that in the PoF exam
learning.explanation: This is quite close to being an instrumentation question, but has been seen in PoF exams recently. If the pitot tubes get blocked in the climb, but the static ports remain free, then the indicated airspeed will initially stop changing with airspeed, and will now gradually increase with altitude as the static pressure reduces (acts like an altimeter). They tell us this in the question, perhaps because we are not expected to know that in the PoF exam. In the climb, this may not be noticeable for a while, and might not be noticed at all if the autopilot was in certain modes, such as those which maintain a constant rate of climb (assuming constant thrust). Whatever happens, as the aircraft continues to climb, the actual airspeed is unknown whilst the indicated airspeed (IAS) is showing a continuous increase. If the aircraft does not stall beforehand, then when maximum airspeed is reached, the pilots or autopilot/autothrottle will either reduce thrust or pitch up to avoid further airspeed increase, which will very quickly lead to a stall. As for the other options, the air data computer, autopilot and autothrottle systems have the same pitot inputs as the pilots do, so will not be able to protect the aircraft from this condition, that is one of the reasons that probe icing and blockages are so dangerous.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
For polar curves (CL vs CD), if the first line represents the polar curve of a clean wing, extending which of the following devices would cause the line to move from position L1 to position L2.

options.A: Lift dumpers.
options.B: Landing gear.
options.C: Trailing edge flaps.
options.D: Speedbrakes.

key_points: The polar diagram of CL vs CD is a very common one to be used in the exams
It takes every angle of attack of the wing, and plots the corresponding CL and CD values as a point on the graph
It is not as easy to read as a standard graph, but once you get used to that, it becomes quite simple
learning.explanation: The polar diagram of CL vs CD is a very common one to be used in the exams. It takes every angle of attack of the wing, and plots the corresponding CL and CD values as a point on the graph. It is not as easy to read as a standard graph, but once you get used to that, it becomes quite simple. The CL is the lift coefficient and the CD is the drag coefficient. Using this, we can see that the point of highest lift coefficient is at the top of the graph, and has quite a high drag coefficient too. That must be CLMAX and is therefore the point just before the stall. Before that point is the best lift to drag ratio, where the CL is highest for the lowest CD (dashed line). We can infer from this that the faster speeds are closer to the origin, and the speeds get slower as the graph continues. We can therefore imagine what each of the options would do to the graph, and measure that up with the annex in the question. "Lift dumpers" Lift dumpers such as wing spoilers reduce lift (as per their name) by ruining the airflow over the wing, and increase drag through this very same method, and by putting an obstruction in the airflow. They would cause the graph to go down and to the right. "Landing Gear" Landing Gear won't affect our lift, but they will increase drag, so the graph will move to the right only, not downwards like we see in the annex. "Trailing Edge Flaps" Flaps increase our CLMAX and also increase drag, so the graph would move up and to the right, which is exactly what is shown in the annex, so this is correct. "Speedbrakes" Aircraft speedbrakes are effectively the same thing as lift dumpers, but often used at lower angles to increase drag whilst avoiding a complete destruction of the lift over the wing. The graph would move down and to the right.
