content.question:
Consider two twin-engine airplanes:
Airplane 1 has clockwise-rotating propellers.
Airplane 2 has inward-rotating propellers.
If, on both airplanes, the left engine fails, which will give the largest yawing moment, and from which side will it be?

options.A: Airplane 1 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the right.
options.B: Airplane 1 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the left.
options.C: Airplane 2 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the right.
options.D: Airplane 2 will have the greatest yaw moment, and it will produce a yaw to the left.

key_points: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine
Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine
The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails
learning.explanation: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine. Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine. The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails. One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following an engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (i.e., distance from the aircraft's CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). In case of a propeller engine aircraft, the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. When the aircraft is flying with a positive angle of attack (which is normal), the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller (when viewed from the rear) is displaced to the right of the engine centre line. This is because the down-going blade generates more thrust than the up-going blade (P-factor). If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a larger yawing moment. If both engines rotate inward, they will have the same (shorter) thrust arm (counter-rotating propellers). Of course, no matter the direction of the propellers, a failure of the left engine will always produce a yaw to the left, it is just bigger if the aircraft has clockwise rotation propellers.

content.question: Consider a multi-engine aircraft equipped with clockwise propellers, flying straight and level. If the critical engine failed, with crosswind from the left, it would result in…

options.A: Yaw moment to the left, crosswind and p factor increase tendency.
options.B: Yaw moment to the right, crosswind and p factor increase tendency.
options.C: Yaw moment to the left, crosswind increases and p factor decreases tendency.
options.D: Yaw moment to the left, crosswind decreases and p factor increases tendency.

key_points: ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT ('p factor') In general, the propeller shaft will be inclined upwards from the direction of flight due to the angle of attack of the aircraft
This gives the down-going propeller blade a greater effective angle of attack than the up-going blade

When viewed from behind if the propeller rotation is clockwise the right side of the disc produces more thrust than the left side and this imbalance of thrust will cause the aeroplane to yaw to the left and vice versa if rotation is anticlockwise
learning.explanation: ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT ('p factor') In general, the propeller shaft will be inclined upwards from the direction of flight due to the angle of attack of the aircraft. This gives the down-going propeller blade a greater effective angle of attack than the up-going blade. When viewed from behind if the propeller rotation is clockwise the right side of the disc produces more thrust than the left side and this imbalance of thrust will cause the aeroplane to yaw to the left and vice versa if rotation is anticlockwise. A similar imbalance of thrust is produced between the top and bottom of the propeller disc if the aeroplane is yawed in level flight. This is because the upper and lower blades will have different angles of attack and as a result will cause the nose of the aeroplane to pitch-up or down depending on the direction of rotation and the direction of the yaw. When viewed from behind if the propeller is rotating clockwise and the yaw is to the left then the lower blade has the greatest angle of attack and produces more lift which causes the nose to pitch up. If the yaw is to the right the nose will pitch-down. The asymmetric-blade effect increases when the angle between the propeller axis and the airflow through the disc increases or if the engine power increases. CRITICAL ENGINE One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (distance from the CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a bigger yawing moment; a higher IAS (VMC) would be necessary to maintain directional control. So at a given IAS, the situation would be more critical if the left engine failed. The critical engine is the engine, the failure of which would give the biggest yawing moment. During a crosswind take-off an airplane tends to weathercock into wind. Because of this the failure of the outboard engine on the windward side of the airplane is the most difficult to counteract.

content.question: A manufacturer has built a large aeroplane in accordance with CS-25, and wishes to perform a test flight to determine its VMCG. A take-off must be planned with the most (1)_____ centre of gravity, and when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative during the take-off run, the pilot must be able to maintain directional control (2)_____ the use of nose wheel steering.

options.A: (1) unfavorable; (2) without
options.B: (1) unfavorable; (2) with
options.C: (1) forward; (2) with
options.D: (1) forward; (2) without

key_points: VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the takeoff run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill
The rudder control forces may not exceed 150 pounds (68
1 kg) and, until the aeroplane becomes airborne, the lateral control may only be used to the extent of keeping the wings level
learning.explanation: VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the takeoff run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill. The rudder control forces may not exceed 150 pounds (68.1 kg) and, until the aeroplane becomes airborne, the lateral control may only be used to the extent of keeping the wings level. In the determination of VMCG, assuming that the path of the aeroplane accelerating with all engines operating is along the centre of the runway, its path from the point at which the critical engine is made inoperative to the point at which recovery to a direction parallel to the centre line is completed may not deviate more than 30 ft (9.144 m) laterally from the centre line at any point. As with VMCA, this must be established with: maximum available take-off power or thrust on the engines. the aeroplane trimmed for take-off. the most unfavourable CG position. maximum sea level take-off weight. Because the aircraft rotates around the CG, the position of the CG directly affects the length of the rudder arm and, thus, the power of the rudder and fin to maintain directional stability and control. The ‘worst case’ is with the CG at the aft limit. If the requirements can be met in this configuration, the ability to maintain directional control will be enhanced at any other CG location. A more forward CG decreases VMCG.

content.question:
You are flying from town A to airport B with a single engine piston when you experience an engine failure. Calculate the minimum altitude at A to reach to airport B, given:
Elevation of town A and airport B: 300 m
Distance from A to B: 60 km
L/D ratio: 30

key_points: Lift over drag (L/D) ratio determines the gliding range
The Glide ratio of an aircraft is the distance of forward travel divided by the altitude lost in that distance
If L/D = 30 => Aircraft will fly 30 units over the ground per every unit down (assuming no wind)
learning.explanation: Lift over drag (L/D) ratio determines the gliding range. The Glide ratio of an aircraft is the distance of forward travel divided by the altitude lost in that distance. If L/D = 30 => Aircraft will fly 30 units over the ground per every unit down (assuming no wind). Ground distance = 60 km = 60 000 m Therefore, with a ground distance of 60 000 m (60 km) and L/D of 30, we get the following equation: 1 / 30 = x / 60 000 x = 2 000 m Now, we must add the elevation of 300 m. Minimum altitude = 2 000 m + 300 m = 2 300 m Note: Altitude - The vertical distance of an object measured from mean sea level. Height -The vertical distance of a level, a point, or an object considered as a point, measured from a specified datum.

content.question:
Which of these statements about the equilibrium of forces and moments at VMCA are correct or incorrect?
I. Equilibrium of moments about the normal axis. is provided by rudder deflection.
II. Equilibrium of forces along the lateral axis does not require any side slip during a wings level condition.

options.A: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: If an engine fails during the take-off of a multi-engine aircraft a significant yawing moment will be experienced due to asymmetric thrust
In order to maintain directional control and keeping the aircraft in equilibrium around the yaw axis, the pilot must apply corrective action
Above a certain speed this will be possible using aerodynamic controls only
learning.explanation: If an engine fails during the take-off of a multi-engine aircraft a significant yawing moment will be experienced due to asymmetric thrust. In order to maintain directional control and keeping the aircraft in equilibrium around the yaw axis, the pilot must apply corrective action. Above a certain speed this will be possible using aerodynamic controls only. If the aircraft is still on the ground this means the use of the rudder, if the aircraft is airborne, the pilot can also apply bank by using the ailerons. The greater the thrust of this operating engine(s), the greater the yawing moment will be and the greater the aerodynamic forces to counteract this yawing moment would be required. VMCA = Minimum control speed in the take-off configuration with gear up – the minimum calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control and maintain straight flight using no more than 5° of bank without required exceptional piloting skill or the aeroplane adopting a dangerous attitude or changing heading by more than 20°. An increased bank angle beyond 5°, while keeping the rudder centered, may lead to a fin stall, due to an extreme sideslip angle, but when decreasing the bank angle below 5° to 0°, rudder deflection has to be increased and therefore VMCA will increase, too. Equilibrium of moments about the normal axis (also called yaw or vertical axis) is provided by rudder deflection (yaw) Equilibrium of moments about the lateral axis is provided by elevator deflection (pitch) Equilibrium of moments about the longitudinal axis is provided by aileron deflection (roll) Note: Forces along the lateral axis is not the same like moments around the lateral axis. Forces along the lateral axis act around the longitudinal axis. Therefore an equilibrium along the lateral axis always requires bank or sideslip.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft changes its heading to the right, from 214º to 334º and makes a rate-1 turn. The duration of this manoeuvre is...

options.A: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's TAS.
options.B: 40 seconds.
options.C: 30 seconds.
options.D: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's angle of bank.

key_points: If the turn is unbalanced, an aircraft either slips into, or skids out of the turn, thereby reducing the aerodynamic efficiency of the aircraft

To help correct for these unwanted conditions, the aircraft is flown using the balance part of the turn and balance indicator During a balanced turn the ball remains in the centre of the balance indicator and the pilot remains upright in the seat relative to the aircraft, with no tendency to lean

learning.explanation: If an engine fails during the take-off of a multi-engine aircraft a significant yawing moment will be experienced due to asymmetric thrust. In order to maintain directional control and keeping the aircraft in equilibrium around the yaw axis, the pilot must apply corrective action. Above a certain speed this will be possible using aerodynamic controls only. If the aircraft is still on the ground this means the use of the rudder, if the aircraft is airborne, the pilot can also apply bank by using the ailerons. The greater the thrust of this operating engine(s), the greater the yawing moment will be and the greater the aerodynamic forces to counteract this yawing moment would be required. VMCA = Minimum control speed in the take-off configuration with gear up – the minimum calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control and maintain straight flight using no more than 5° of bank without required exceptional piloting skill or the aeroplane adopting a dangerous attitude or changing heading by more than 20°. An increased bank angle beyond 5°, while keeping the rudder centered, may lead to a fin stall, due to an extreme sideslip angle, but when decreasing the bank angle below 5° to 0°, rudder deflection has to be increased and therefore VMCA will increase, too. Equilibrium of moments about the normal axis (also called yaw or vertical axis) is provided by rudder deflection (yaw) Equilibrium of moments about the lateral axis is provided by elevator deflection (pitch) Equilibrium of moments about the longitudinal axis is provided by aileron deflection (roll) Note: Forces along the lateral axis is not the same like moments around the lateral axis. Forces along the lateral axis act around the longitudinal axis. Therefore an equilibrium along the lateral axis always requires bank or sideslip.

Calculate the turn radius for an aircraft with a TAS of 120 kt and a 60° bank angle.
(Assume g = 10 m/s2)

81 m/s2, but assumed to be 10 m/s2 in some questions, like this one
All units are in metric
learning.explanation: The formula to work out radius of turn is; Radius = (TAS)2 / (g x tan(bank angle)) Where g = the acceleration due to gravity, usually 9.81 m/s2, but assumed to be 10 m/s2 in some questions, like this one. All units are in metric. Radius (m), TAS (m/s), g (m/s2). First lets convert 120 kt into metres per second. 120 kt is 120 nautical miles per 1 hour, so multiple by the amount of metres in a nautical mile [1852] (now you have metres per hour). Then divide by the amount of seconds in an hour [3600]. Now you have metres per second. TAS = 120 kt x 1852 / 3600 = 61.73 m/s Substituting the known figures into the radius formula above, we get; Radius (m) = (61.73)2 / (10 x tan(60º)) = 220 m

learning.explanation: TURNING For an aircraft to change direction, a force is required to deflect it towards the centre of the turn. This is called the centripetal force. Banking the aircraft inclines the lift - it is the horizontal component of lift which causes the aircraft to turn. If the aircraft is banked and the angle of attack kept constant, the vertical component of lift will be too small to balance the weight and the aircraft will start to descend. As the angle of bank increases, the angle of attack must be increased to bring about a greater total lift. The vertical component must be large enough to maintain level flight, while the horizontal component is large enough to produce the required centripetal force. If the same TAS and angle of bank can be obtained, the radius of turn is basically independent of weight or the aircraft type. Not all aircraft can reach the same angle of bank at the same TAS. If weight increases, the vertical component of lift required increases, but the centripetal force to maintain the same radius of turn also increases in the same proportion. The lift required, although it is greater, has the same inclination to the vertical as before and the bank angle is the same.

learning.explanation: Short explanation: At low density altitude, the engine generates more thrust at full power. More thrust means a greater yawing moment which requires a greater counterbalancing moment from the fin. Greater fin force requires a higher speed to generate it. Consequently, your calculated minimum control speeds are faster in cold, low altitude conditions (higher air density). In simple words, VMCG is established as being the lowest speed at which rudder effect alone is sufficient to regain and maintain directional control after a sudden engine failure. The major factor that affects VMCG is the difference in engine thrust. VMCG will therefore be lower at higher airport elevations and at a higher OAT (lower air density), due to the associated lower thrust. Conversely, VMCG will be higher at lower airport elevations and at a lower OAT (higher air density). If conditions are hot, high and humid the air is less dense. This reduces thrust and, consequently, when you lose the critical engine on take-off, there is less yawing effect from asymmetric thrust than there would be in denser air.

content.question:
Given:
Aeroplane mass: 50000 kg. Lift/Drag ratio: 12.
Thrust per engine: 20000 N. Assumed g: 10 m/s².
For a straight, steady, wings level climb of a four-engine aeroplane, the all-engines climb gradient is:

key_points: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal
γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle
The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity
learning.explanation: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal. γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle. The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity. Weight is resolved into two components: one opposite Lift (W cos γ) and the other acting in the same direction as Drag (W sin γ), backwards along the flight path. The requirements for equilibrium are: Thrust must equal the sum of Drag plus the backwards component of Weight; and Lift must equal its opposing component of Weight. For equilibrium at a greater angle of climb, the Lift required will be less, and the backwards component of Weight will be greater. L = W cos γ T = D + W sin γ In a straight steady climb, Lift is less than Weight because Lift only has to support a proportion of the weight, this proportion decreasing as the climb angle increases. The remaining proportion of Weight is supported by engine Thrust. It can be seen that for a straight steady climb the Thrust required is greater than Drag. This is to balance the backward component of Weight acting along the flight path. The climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T−D)/W For very shallow flight path angles (γ), we can assume that lift is approximately equal to Weight, therefore the climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = T/W−D/L In this exercise, Weight is equal to 500000 N (W = m x g = 50000 x 10), D/L ratio is equal to 1/12 and Thrust equal to 20000 N per engine. For the all engines (four) climb gradient and applying the formula defined above: sin γ = (80000/500000)−(1/12) sinγ = 0.077 ⇒ sinγ = 7.7% The climb gradient is 7.7%.

learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. If the airspeed is too low, the yawing moments due to the failed engine may even make the aircraft uncontrollable. With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force).

What will happen to the rate of descent if an aircraft descending at VMD slows down?

key_points: An aircraft's angle of descent is calculated by the formula: (Drag - Thrust) / Weight = sin(Descent angle) Which, when gliding is just: Drag / Weight = sin(Descent angle) This means that minimum drag will always give us minimum angle of descent, so VMD is always going to provide the longest range in a descent, which is particularly important to know, as gliding in a powered aircraft is usually trying to get to a safe landing site
Similar to the way we improve our rate of climb by going much faster up a smaller climb angle, we can also descend slower, by having a steeper descent angle but a much lower speed
Nicely, this speed where we get best glide endurance is VMP, the speed for minimum power required
learning.explanation: An aircraft's angle of descent is calculated by the formula: (Drag - Thrust) / Weight = sin(Descent angle) Which, when gliding is just: Drag / Weight = sin(Descent angle) This means that minimum drag will always give us minimum angle of descent, so VMD is always going to provide the longest range in a descent, which is particularly important to know, as gliding in a powered aircraft is usually trying to get to a safe landing site. Similar to the way we improve our rate of climb by going much faster up a smaller climb angle, we can also descend slower, by having a steeper descent angle but a much lower speed. Nicely, this speed where we get best glide endurance is VMP, the speed for minimum power required. It gives us a steeper descent angle, but at a much slower airspeed, so our actual rate of descent is lower, and we can remain in the air for longer. VMP is a slower speed than VMD. Therefore, beginning at VMD and decreasing airspeed, the rate of descent will initially decrease, until reaching VMP, and then will begin to increase again, with the high induced drag at low speeds.

learning.explanation: A straight and steady power-on descent, with a certain power setting at which the engine creates a thrust vector, results in four forces acting on the airplane, i.e., weight, lift, thrust and drag. The force of weight can be resolved into two components. The required rate of descent to maintain a particular glidepath (usually 3° where possible) is based solely on the aircraft's groundspeed. learning.explanation: RATE OF CLIMB The rate of climb is defined as the height change over a given time period, usually expressed in feet per minute or metres per second. Wind component has no effect on the rate of climb. It can be expressed by: Rate of climb = Angle of climb x TAS The magnitude of the rate of climb is determined by the excess power available over that required. The value of the rate of climb is diminished by high altitude, high temperature, high mass and high flap setting either individually or in any combination. Any acceleration or a turn made whilst climbing also reduces the rate of climb. Because power is the rate of doing work then when dealing with a rate of climb the power curves must be used. To attain the maximum rate of climb the aircraft must be flown at the speed attained, at the point on the graph, at which the excess power available over that required is greatest. Rate of Climb = (T x TAS) – (D x TAS) / W So, Rate of Climb = (Power Available – Power Required) / W ALTITUDE vs. POWER REQUIRED Power required is drag times TAS. Although the total drag curve as a CAS does not move as altitude increases, it moves to the right if drawn against TAS. This is because for the same CAS, the TAS increases as the air density reduces. Figure 2 plots power available and power required against TAS and shows us that as altitude increases: - The excess power and rate of climb reduce - VY (TAS) increases to a slightly faster speed VARIATION OF THRUST WITH ALTITUDE As altitude increases, thrust available reduces because the air density and, therefore, mass flow reduce. content.question: If the thrust line is located above an aeroplane’s CG, it will create a...

options.B: positive pitch moment that is destabilising.
options.C: negative pitch moment that is destabilising.
options.D: negative pitch moment that is stabilising.

key_points: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability
The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
learning.explanation: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability. The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. Therefore, the effect is destabilizing. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

content.question: In a straight and steady descent, the...

options.B: shallower the descent angle, the greater the difference between total weight and lift.
options.C: total weight must be equal to lift for the aeroplane to be in equilibrium.
options.D: steeper the descent angle, the greater the difference between total weight and lift.

key_points: The balance of forces in steady descent show that a component of the weight is adding to the thrust of the aircraft (if any thrust is available)
To think of it another way, the weight is being counteracted by a component of the lift, and a component of the drag, which is now acting a little upwards also
Because the drag is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in steady descent show that a component of the weight is adding to the thrust of the aircraft (if any thrust is available). To think of it another way, the weight is being counteracted by a component of the lift, and a component of the drag, which is now acting a little upwards also. Because the drag is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight. There are two usual equations that can be made from this graph. The first is all about the forwards/backwards forces on the aircraft: Drag = Thrust + [Weight x sin(Descent Angle)] The second equation is all about up/down forces on the aircraft: Lift = Weight x cos(Descent Angle) This second equation is the one that this question asks about. As the descent angle increases (the descent gets steeper), cos(Decent Angle) decreases, so Lift decreases. Weight has not changed, but the Lift has decreased (as drag is acting upwards against the weight), so the difference between the two increases. Also, this means that load factor (Lift/Weight) decreases in a descent and climb too. The second equation can be used in the descent or the climb.

content.question: An aeroplane with a mass of 2000 kg, is performing a co-ordinated level turn at a constant TAS of 160 kt and the bank angle is 60°. The lift is approximately:

key_points: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated

A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn
If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn
learning.explanation: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated. A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn. If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn. The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. Either condition will be indicated on the turn and slip indicator. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. To maintain altitude and airspeed when executing a turn both the angle of attack and the thrust have to be increased above their level flight values. In a turn, the load factor (n) is defined by: n = L/W = 1/cos Φ On a 60° bank turn, to maintain the same lift as in straight and level flight, with a weight of 20000 N, L/20000 = 1/cos 60 L = 20000 * 1/cos⁡ 60 L = 40000 N Lift is equal to 40000 N.

content.question: In a steady co-ordinated horizontal turn, lift is:

options.B: greater than in straight and level flight because it must balance the centripetal force.
options.C: equal to the aeroplane weight.
options.D: greater than in straight and level flight, because it must generate the centrifugal force.

key_points: In a steady horizontal turn, the total lift is greater than the weight
The conditions of equilibrium can be expressed in the form: L cos φ = W L = W / cos φ Where (L) is the wing lift in newtons, (W) is the weight of the aircraft in newtons and φ the angle of bank
TIP: Remember that in a turn, lift will be greater than the weight to remain at the same altitude
learning.explanation: In a steady horizontal turn, the total lift is greater than the weight. The conditions of equilibrium can be expressed in the form: L cos φ = W L = W / cos φ Where (L) is the wing lift in newtons, (W) is the weight of the aircraft in newtons and φ the angle of bank. TIP: Remember that in a turn, lift will be greater than the weight to remain at the same altitude. The cosine of any angle other than 0º is less than 1 => for L to be greater than W, the equation must be L cos φ = W (any bank angle requires a larger lift to balance the same weight). Due to the bank angle (φ) of the aircraft, the lift vector is tilted, therefore only a component of lift counteracts weight. But since level flight must be maintained, the component of lift has to be equal to weight. Consequently, lift must be increased. Centripetal force is the force generated towards the centre of turn and its magnitude depends on the radius of the turn and speed. Centripetal force is generated by additional lift. Note: Centrifugal force is the reaction to the centripetal force generated by the extra lift and acts towards the outside of the turn.

The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g)

learning.explanation: Load Factor - The ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the load imposed by lift. The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g). Load Factor = Lift / Weight Where, Lift = 1⁄2 x ρ x V2 x CL x S LOAD FACTOR IN A TURN When an aircraft is in a banked turn, lift must be increased so as to maintain the vertical component of lift equal to weight. Load Factor (n) increases with bank angle at an increasing rate. If speed is kept constant, but the bank angle increased, the angle of attack must also be increased to provide the increased lift required. Because induced drag is a component of the lift force, the greater the lift, the greater will be the induced drag. Lift must be equal to weight in level flight so induced drag will depend on the weight of the aircraft. Induced drag will be greater at higher aircraft weights. Certain manoeuvres require the lift force to be greater than the aircraft weight For example, lift is greater than weight during a steady turn so induced drag will be higher during a steady turn than in straight and level flight. Therefore, induced drag also increases as the Load Factor increases. Induced drag will increase in proportion to the square of the lift force: CDI = CL2 / AR In this example, doubling the Load factor requires the Lift Coefficient to be double as well (considering all other factor remain constant). From the above formula, we can conclude that doubling the Lift Coefficient will cause the Induced Drag Coefficient to be 4 times greater.

The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity. Weight is resolved into two components: one opposite Lift (W cos γ) and the other acting in the same direction as Drag (W sin γ), backwards along the flight path. The requirements for equilibrium are: Thrust must equal the sum of Drag plus the backwards component of Weight; and Lift must equal its opposing component of Weight. For equilibrium at a greater angle of climb, the Lift required will be less, and the backwards component of Weight will be greater. L = W cosγ T = D + W sinγ In a straight steady climb, Lift is less than Weight because Lift only has to support a proportion of the weight, this proportion decreasing as the climb angle increases. The remaining proportion of Weight is supported by engine Thrust. It can be seen that for a straight steady climb the Thrust required is greater than Drag. This is to balance the backward component of Weight acting along the flight path. The climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T−D)/W For very shallow flight path angles (γ), we can assume that lift is approximately equal to Weight, therefore the climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = T/W−D/L In this exercise, Weight is equal to 500000 N, D/L ratio is equal to 1/12 and Thrust equal to 28000 N per engine. For the all engines (three) climb gradient and applying the formula defined above: sin γ = (84000/500000) −(1/12) sinγ = 0.085 ⇒ sinγ = 8.5% The climb gradient is 8.5%.

content.question: What could happen as a consequence of climbing to a higher level using the autopilot "Vertical Speed" (V/S) mode?

options.A: Decreasing airspeed and the aeroplane may stall.
options.B: Increasing airspeed and the aeroplane may stall.
options.C: Increased risk of super stall.
options.D: Use of VS mode is not permitted in the climb.

key_points: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode
In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S
The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH
learning.explanation: Vertical Speed is an autopilot flight guidance vertical mode. In this mode, the Flight Management and Guidance Computer (FMCG) pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S. The corresponding thrust mode is SPEED or MACH. The V/S guidance has priority over the speed guidance. If the selected target V/S is too high (relative to the current thrust condition and speed), the FMGC will steer the aircraft to the target V/S, but the aircraft will also accelerate or decelerate. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting. Consequently, the angle of attack also reduces. As a result, the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. The autopilot will therefore chase the selected vertical speed by pitching up. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

The vital action when an engine fails is to stop the yaw. The rolling and yawing moments and the power of the flight controls to balance them will determine the controllability of an aircraft with asymmetric thrust. Rolling and yawing moments with asymmetric thrust are affected by: Thrust on the live engine Altitude Drag from the dead engine and propeller Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) CG position The fore and aft CG location has no effect on the yawing moment from a failed engine, but will influence the rudder arm, hence the rudder moment. content.question: A twin engine jet transport aeroplane is taking off from runway 27 with a wind of 210°/15 kt and an outside Air Temperature (OAT) of 20 °C. The failure of which engine would require the largest control inputs to maintain runway centreline?

options.A: It makes no difference.
options.B: Failure of the left engine.
options.C: It depends on the direction of rotation of the engines.
options.D: Failure of the right engine.

key_points: During a crosswind take-off, an airplane tends to weathercock into wind (yaw into the wind), due to the wind acting on the fin which produces a yaw moment
In this case, the aircraft is taking-off from RW27 with a wind of 210/15 kt (from the left), the aircraft will tend to yaw left
If a right engine fails, the left side will produce much more thrust than the right side, resulting in a right-yaw
learning.explanation: During a crosswind take-off, an airplane tends to weathercock into wind (yaw into the wind), due to the wind acting on the fin which produces a yaw moment. In this case, the aircraft is taking-off from RW27 with a wind of 210/15 kt (from the left), the aircraft will tend to yaw left. If a right engine fails, the left side will produce much more thrust than the right side, resulting in a right-yaw. This will oppose the yaw-left moment. If a left engine fails, the right side will produce more thrust than the left side, resulting in a left-yaw. This will add to the left-yaw moments. Therefore, the failure of the engine on the windward side of the airplane is the most difficult to counteract.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The attached figure shows an aeroplane in cruise flight suffering an engine failure with significant damage. The pilot knows that if they enter the clouds it will cause significant turbulence making it more difficult to handle the failure. To avoid entering the clouds and to maintain its current flight path tracking, the pilot must apply...

options.A: right rudder to balance any yawing moments and maintain straight flight, and right aileron to generate a sideslip towards the live engine, achieving a net zero sideslip.
options.B: right rudder as this will cause the aeroplane to continue coordinated flight as the rudder will offset the left yawing moment from the live engine.
options.C: right aileron as this will cause the aeroplane to sideslip towards the live engine and offset the yaw created by the live engine as well as achieving coordinated flight.
options.D: left rudder as this will cause the aeroplane to sideslip towards the live engine and reduce the effect of asymmetric thrust along the flight path.

key_points: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability

With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis
If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine
learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force). Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine It is more aerodynamically efficient to balance the rudder sideforce by banking towards the live engine, so that lift gives a sideways component opposite to the rudder force. The angle of bank must not exceed 5°, to prevent excessive loss of vertical lift component. Banking towards the live engine also reduces the side force on the fin from sideslip, which minimizes VMC, effectively reduces the yawing moment and gives more rudder authority to stop the yaw. The cockpit indication will be the turn needle central with the slip indicator (ball) one half diameter displaced towards the live engine. The ‘ball’ is not centred, but the aircraft is not sideslipping.

content.question: Approximately how long does it take to fly a complete circle during a horizontal steady co-ordinated turn with a bank angle of 45° and a TAS of 200 kt?

key_points: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated

A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn
If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn
learning.explanation: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated. A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn. If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn. The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. Either condition will be indicated on the turn and slip indicator. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. To maintain altitude and airspeed when executing a turn both the angle of attack and the thrust have to be increased above their level flight values. In a turn, turn radius and rate of turn are defined as: Turn radius = TAS 2/g tan Φ Rate of Turn = g tan Φ/TAS Therefore, turn radius is directly proportional to TAS squared and inversely proportional to bank angle and Rate of Turn is directly proportional to bank angle and inversely proportional to TAS. In this exercise, TAS is equal to 200 knots and the bank angle is 45°: First, convert 200kt to m/s: 200kt x 0.5144 = 102.88m/s Then, calculate the turn radius Turn radius = 102.88 2/10 x tan 45 Turn radius ≈ 1058.43m The circumference is given by: c = 2 * π * r c = 2 * π * 1058.43 c = 6650.31 m At 102.88 m/s, it would take approximately 65 seconds to complete the circumference.

content.question: During the initial climb out, the pilot is required to do a 15° turn to the left to avoid an obstacle. The total drag will:

options.A: Decrease and the climb gradient will increase.
options.B: Increase and the climb gradient will increase.
options.C: Increase and the climb gradient will decrease.
options.D: Decrease and the climb gradient will decrease.

key_points: Any manoeuvre such as a turn calls for more lift
Due to the bank angle of the aircraft, the lift vector is tilted, therefore only a component of lift counteracts weight
But since level flight must be maintained, the component of lift has to be equal to weight
learning.explanation: Any manoeuvre such as a turn calls for more lift. Due to the bank angle of the aircraft, the lift vector is tilted, therefore only a component of lift counteracts weight. But since level flight must be maintained, the component of lift has to be equal to weight. Consequently, lift must be increased. By increasing the bank angle, load factor increases. Due to increased lift, induced drag also increases producing greater drag, this in turn increases total drag. For a given aircraft mass the maximum climb gradient will occur when the excess thrust over drag is greatest. As seen above, the drag increases in a turn, provided that thrust remains the same, the climb gradient will decrease.
